title: How to crack the UPSC CSE in the first attempt while being under any circumstances - Quora
tags: Union Public Service Commission of India

response.answer_text: I will share my story and the strategy that I followed to clear the coveted Civil Services Exam in the first attempt. First of all, let me tell you a bit about myself. Civil services was never childhood dream. I did not start preparing from my school days and if anyone tells you that you need to start preparing from 8th standard, it is a myth and do not take them at face value. I did my B.Tech from College of Engineering, Trivandrum in Kerala. After graduating in 2015 I was working with ITC Limited, as a mechanical engineer. It was during my stint at ITC that I decided to prepare. So, I put in my papers in the June of 2016 and started preparing from July 2016. Term of preparation:- I started my preps from July 2016 and wrote Prelims in June 2017. So that is a total of 11 months of focused preparation before appearing for CSE 2017. So let me now come to the topic of how to crack civil services in the first attempt. These are some prerequisites that anyone should have before starting their preparation. Unflinching self belief:- No one in the world is going to believe in you and your capabilities. And every tom, dick and harry will not miss any opportunity to question your abilities and to blame you for every decision. So you of all people should believe in you, without that kind of confidence in yourself, seeing through this exam would become a Herculean task.Having an original plan/strategy:- Before I started my preparation for civil services, I had gone through strategies of many toppers. What I found out was that no two people had cleared this exam with the same strategy, but the common factor that runs through all those toppers were that they had their own strategies. Now that is rule number one. Do not blindly follow the strategy shown to you by a coaching institute or any topper, you need to have your own plan which magnifies your strong points and diminishes your weaknesses.Be tougher than the exam:- The civil services exam is dubiously dubbed as the toughest exam in the world. So to master the exam you need to tougher than it. You need to be prepared to face failures and get up and fight back stronger.Know your syllabus:- The most common mistake that most aspirants make is that they fail to go through the syllabus for the exam. Knowing what the syllabus demands and not demands is absolutely necessary fpr clearing this exam. Only then will we be able to target our efforts for quick results. Merely pouring through volumes and volumes of history and geography is not what the exam demands. there is a very highly defined syllabus and our effort should be to cover as much of the syllabus with as much clarity as possible.It is breadth that matters and not depth:- The Civil Services Exam is an examination to recruit generalist bureaucrats who would be able to handle any department under the government. The exam, therefore, demands the exact same thing, your vastness and breadth of understanding matters and not depth of understanding in any subject. A common mistake that I have seen aspirants make is that they try to cover a subject from cover to cover and in the end amassing as much knowledge in the subject as a PhD holder in that subject would have. Whereas the exam demands a mere fraction of that knowledge.Should one attend a coaching class to clear Civil Service Exam? This is perhaps the first decision any civil service aspirant will have to make before starting your preparation. Now this is highly subjective. Given the huge amount of online content that is available now-a-days it is perfectly possible to clear the CSE without joining any coaching institute. But I had enrolled at a coaching centre in Kerala. I did so because, at the start of my preparation I had absolutely no idea about the exam or how to prepare for the same. So for me some amount of guidance and handholding was necessary for me. Now I should add a word of caution here. Even if a candidate decides to join some coaching class there is only so much classes can do (at best say 20–30% of the work might get done in a classroom), it will entirely depend on how much effort that you put in that will decide your result. What books should I read? This is again a very subjective topic and there is not a single comprehensive book list that will help you clear this exam. NCERT Text books of history, geography, economics and polity from class Vi to XII are a must read in my opinion. Reading these books will help you cover and basics and create a strong foundation which you can supplement with your further reading. Personally almost 60% of my knowledge base for the static subjects come from NCERT text books. Below is a list of books that I followed for my preparation.  The key here is to select the books you are comfortable with and to stick with them. Reading all the material that comes out daily is both impractical and unfruitful. Reading the same texts multiple times will be much more beneficial. How important is newspaper reading? Newspapers are vital for any preparation strategy. I used to spend atleast 2–3 hours daily reading the newspaper. It helps one cement the concepts and helps you evolve opinions and will help you analyse a given situation from multiple perspectives. This will come in handy especially during mains and interview stages. I used to prepare notes from The Hindu daily on the evernote app. This helped me stay organised. During the last 2 months of prelims preparation, I further reduced my one year worth of newspaper notes into crisp notes that filled one 100 page notebook. I read this condensed version multiple times and was the major source for current affairs preparation for prelims as well as mains. How important is mock exams? Mocks tests are very very very very very important in all the three stages of the exam. I cannot stress the importance of mock tests any more. For Prelims, giving lot of mock tests will help you refine your strategy to maximise your scoring. For some answering only those questions which they are absolutely sure of will do the trick. Whereas for someone else (like me) maximizing the number of attempts may help clear the cut off. And there is only one way to find out the strategy that will work for you, do umpteen number of mock exams. Perhaps, mock tests for mains are the most important. In mains it is not how much you know that matters, but how well you can articulate the things that you know in the limited time that is available. Mains answer writing is a skill, which can be mastered only with practice. Choosing the right optional subject The optional paper can make or break your career. So be very careful in choosing your optional. Your criteria while choosing the optional should be Do you like the subject, enough to spend thousands of hours pouring over it.Is there good guidance available for the subject. Especially are there good mock tests with good feedback available for the chosen subject.Also check the trend of past few years and check the scoring trend. However this should be the last consideration and the primary consideration should be for your passion for the subject.Pacing your preparation:- It is of utmost importance to rightly pace your preparation so that you never run out of steam. One must start slowly, but steadily build up momentum so that he/she can give the final push close to the examination. But the most important aspect to clearing this exam is to enjoy the journey and not just the destination. One must thoroughly enjoy the preparation phase to be able to bear with the stress that this exam puts on an aspirant. Take it one day at a time, enjoying the learning process and you are sure to succeed. All the very best!!

“Under any circumstances” is a fairly big and wide criterion. Anyways, I will try to answer this question. I have cleared CSE twice, in 2014 with 144th rank and 2015 with 201 rank getting IPS level rank both the time(which was my second preference after IAS). My circumstances were more challenging, I think, during my first attempt: I was in last year of college studying in a 4 year Btech Program of electrical engineering in IIT Delhi2. During my third year, I had opted for academic exchange program to Taiwan. It meant that I missed several compulsory courses and labs which needed to be done in last semester. So unlike a lot of my friends, I didn’t have a chilled out last semester. 3. I started my preparations in 4th year only. 4. I decided to opt for sociology as my optional in which I had very little prior knowledge. 5. My GPA was bordering on 9 and I didn’t want to push it below that. To be clear, I am not saying that my circumstances were the most challenging. Far from it, when I see my batchmates from various services, I feel less and less deserving. It is a great opportunity bestowed on me by almighty. But I would like to give a generic overview of what I did and what helped me. 1. Be clear about your goal: Motivation is the primary criterion here. If you come here for some fallacious reasons like earning more money, one day or the other you are going to get demotivated. For me it was my childhood dream and I never felt as if I can chose an alternative path. 2. Form a timeline: I decided that I will try to be at prelims clearing stage by September –October 2013 so that I have a fair shot at mains 2014. I worked towards that goal and wanted to cover as much of a ground as possible. 3. Analyse: Start by reading online about the people who have cleared these exams. Take a look at their strategy. Special attention must be paid to the section where they analyse what they did in the attempt in which they were unsuccessful. Also analyse your own ability. How much can you memorise? what is your retention capacity? Are you a visual learner or a reader? 4. Be flexible: This exam is not an exam of knowledge only but an exam of values. Accept that you will have to change yourself during the preparations. You have to get yourself ready to be placed in some of the key positions in country’s administration. For example: I never made notes during my JEE preparation or during my college. In fact, my total notes during my college years must have been a single register :P but when I analysed, I realised that it will help me revise quickly and hence I made extensive notes of everything. Even books and then never looked at textbooks and revised from my notes only. 5. Form a concrete strategy: Which textbooks will you read? How will you read them? How will you organise material? All these things must be answered from an individual assessment. Be honest and form a realistic strategy. 6. Stick to your commitment: Once you have formed the strategy stick to it no matter what. Never compromise on it. Read what you decided you would read. If you decided that you will read yojana every month, you have to do it. If you miss it force yourself to read it next month. I have read 60 70 newspapers after backlog because I made a commitment to reading two newspapers a day. Never ever compromise on what you yourself decided. Here are some additional pointers which will help to stick to your strategy: 1. Fill empty spaces: I used to travel around 2 hours to coaching almost everyday(coming and going) from IITD to Old Rajinder Nagar. I used to have a lot of what I call “empty spaces” ie travelling in metro etc. Always revise something or read some random but relevant text during this time. I read so many books during that year of preparation by following this method. 2. Do not make coaching an end in itself: If you feel that a particular class is unhelpful, avoid going. Don’t have a jolly good time instead read the same subject at home. People tend to believe that since they have paid money, they need to “extract everything”. You have paid money to get knowledge not to attend classes. Remember the end purpose. I do not believe that coaching is essential to clear this exam. Infact it tends to make everybody same by giving same perspectives. Broaden your horizon. Focus on the strategy you made rather than what coaching teaches. Coaching focuses on bulk but you are an individual aspiring for a highly individualistic role in government. Be independent! 3. Periodic Assessments: Give tests regularly, if you find a subject relatively weak read a standard text on it. Do not over think and over strategise. Just take a book and start reading. Brute force your way into the list. This will also ensure that since you are focussing on relatively weak subject, over time your all subjects will become strong. It Is a good sign if your relative weakness keeps on changing. It shows you are working on yourself. 4. Do not make it a horrible experience: I read some answers here wanted you to study 15 17 hrs a day. I don’t believe in this. Moreover they also wanted aspirants to shut down their social life and even ask parents not to disturb you(I know in my case that would have ended with a lot of scolding). Friends should also be discarded. You are preparing to be a civil servant and not to attain nirvana. Don’t overemphasise on the penance. Rather enjoy the experience. I attended my farewell and had regular plans with my friends if and when needed. They were also nice enough to change their plans according to my needs. I even sat for placement just for the experience. Never got off facebook for an extended period. Never deactivated whatsapp. I believe I would become mundane if I did such things. Enjoy responsibly. Remember its your fight, commit to it. Whatever time is left is for yourself. Do not feel guilty enjoying it. 6. The optional dilemma: Donot go by market rumors. Make a shortlist of optionals you consider taking. Read basic materials of the same and decide on merit of your own interests and abilities. 5. Accept your conditions but never surrender to them: I have talked to many people and not just IAS/IPS/IFS/IRS who have beaten all odds to become successful. Accept your reality and as lord Tyrion of house Lannister says, wear it like an armor. Never make it as an excuse. Acceptance of your conditions is the first step in surmounting it but never make yourself believe it cannot be done. Make yourself worthy of your goal. If you want to become a civil servant, change your value orientations to becoming sincere, disciplined and committed. The aim of the exam is to mold you, the testing is done to ensure you did what is required. See exam as a journey and your conditions as obstacles. Do not overthink and feel helpless, rather believe everything can be done. Think less work more! If some friends keep talking about how difficult the exam is, stay away from them! Talk to friends to discuss more about food and well life.  Finally just a side note. I generally avoid glorifying the examination. Everybody who has given it accepts that there is huge subjectivity in the exam. Don’t put too much stake into a single exam. It’s a part of life hence always keep a B plan ready. Nobody in this world can guarantee that a person will pass, it requires something more than just right preparations, call it destiny or divine intervention, whatever you like. But enjoy the fact that this exam will surely make you a more aware, confident and disciplined individual and if you achieve that, you will be an asset to the society and country whether you are a civil servant or not. 

Here is my story which may guide you to clear civils in 1st attempt In 2013,My circumstances :- i was in a Job in which i needed to work 8 a.m to 8 p.m with one 3 hour break.Took 4–5 classes per day besides solving doubts of students & preparing tests & study material.Started IAS preparation just around 50 days before prelimsMarriage got fixed next year May…you can understand the ceremonies before that & lots of mental disturbances due to it.Overall In 2013–2014 (Busy Job + Pre Marriage issues + IAS preparation). I took too many tasks and much less time. But as i never wanted to quit my well paying job for civils preparation. I tried to manage my time well by Devoting 7–8 hrs overall to study by focusing on Prelims first. I aimed only to clear prelims that year.Got through prelims quite easily by scoring 282 marks out of 400 as i was quite strong in CSAT part.Confidence increased significantly & so started the UPSC mains preparation the day prelims ended .6 month to go to mainsWritten most of the test of Vision IAS and tried to analyse themGS part was not that strong as i started preparing too late for civils. So,i tried to focus on static parts of GSPrepared Chemistry optional in next 4–5 months …i was able to do it just because i had been teaching chemistry for many years to IIT JEE aspirants.Always kept positive attitude as i had nothing to lose even if my attempt go in vainGave 1st UPSC mains in Dec,2013 and tried to give my best.March 2013,Results of mains declared & i cleared it in the 1st attempt. It was unbelievable & amazing moment for me.Gave UPSC interview on 13th of may,2014 .. exactly 10 days before my marriage :D …So many things were happening simultaneously, was not able to focus on interview preparation much & due to various distractions during the last month. Didn’t get my name in final list.As my story has Taste of success as well as failure, i would be able to correctly advice you in what you should do and what not to :- Try to start UPSC prep as soon as possible..don’t get late in doing upsc prep. Many of my close friends have lost numerous important years of their youth in UPSC preparation.Join a good coaching & follow its routing keeping UPSC syllabus & questions in mind.Decide optional based on your interest & not on what people recommend. If you are good with your optional ,you will always score great.Avoid distractions as much as you can (Social media,negative news,marriage :P,Love or lust affairs )Take good care of the fitnessAlways keep a safety back up career plan in case UPSC plan fails..it will always give you the moral supportYou may take part time teaching as a job..as you will get sustainable income…as well as teaching increases your understanding & other skills..Minimum material & maximum revision of same material is must . Don’t make your home a libraryGood Test series & analysisMost important thing is Don’t lose focus till you clear the interview. I lost my focus after clearing mains & now i am writing this answer on quoraI wish you all the best to succeed in the very 1st attempt ✌

I don’t know whether I am the right person to answer this question or not because I couldn’t clear this exam in all my 6 attempts despite coming very close. But I believe I have ample knowledge about this exam because I gave six years of my life to it. And I think I can at least guide aspirants as to what I feel went wrong with my attempts and preparation so that they don’t commit the same mistakes I made. That way your chances can be improved even though it is difficult to predict whether you will be able to clear this exam in the first attempt or even the last attempt. UPSC CSE is an exam of colossal magnitude and a “logistical challenge” in itself. Moreover UPSC is not called “Unpredictable Service Commission” in the aspirant community for absolutely no reason. Even if you prepare very well and do everything right (which is mathematically very improbable if not impossible), a lot of things can go wrong in this exam at any of the levels. The biggest problem with this exam is that even if you fail at the last stage and by say even 1 mark, you don’t get any consolation prize as in you have to start from the scratch again and it might happen that you may fail to clear prelims itself in this year even though might have gotten selected in the previous year (as it happened to a friend of mine who got IRTS last year and couldn’t even clear prelims this year). You can read other answer in which I have delineated the mistakes I made in all the attempts and why I feel I couldn’t get through: Atul Roy's answer to Why most IAS aspirants fail to qualify prelims and Mains? Clearing this exam in the very first attempt depends on a lot of other factors many of which are not in control of an average aspirant. For example the biggest reason why people from ivy league colleges like IITs, IIMs etc clear this exam in disproportionate numbers is the exposure they get in their colleges. They have world class faculty, better study environments, and most importantly a vibrant and top notch peer group. So they generally don’t make the same mistakes the average aspirants make. I will give you an example. In my first attempt since I didn't have any idea of what to read, I used to read “ChronicKill” (Chronicle) magazine which was tremendous waste of time and energy. But at the same time I had a co aspirant from IIT Delhi (who eventually cleared in his first attempt) and he laughed at us for reading that magazine and never read it. He read basic books and NCERTs and cleared. Since there is so much study material available and so many different strategies floating around it becomes very difficult to know what to read and what not to. And in this exam it is very important to know what not to read even more than what to read. Moreover people think that if someone cleared in the first attempt, everyone can. It may or may not happen. Because someone who clears in first attempt, may have been preparing for a long time before writing the exam e.g. Tina Dabi who had been preparing since 2011, or they must have been very well read even before writing the exam e.g. Prakash Rajpurohit or they might have been simply gifted e.g. Shah Faisal. And this might not be the case with every other aspirant. That is not to imply that this exam can not be prepared and cleared in the first attempt. It can certainly be done. I am below giving in brief the mistakes I committed and how to avoid them so as to better your chances to clear this exam in first attempt. If you want to know in detail you can read my answer I have mentioned above. Here’s some of the mistakes one should avoid ( taken from my answer): Wishfully thinking and daydreaming that one would clear this exam. Most of the time one keeps on planning on what and how to read;thinking about what one would do after clearing the exam and what not, and not actually reading. This is detrimental.Not taking a holistic perspective of this exam. Taking all the different stages as disparate entities whereas this exam is an integrated exam.Being overconfident about one’s abilities. Even if you are/have been a topper throughout your academic or career, you still have to cover a mammoth syllabus which will take time and hard work. And in my opinion intelligence is hyped concept. So many Doctors, IITians & IIM grads fail to clear this exam every year despite putting in efforts. What is required is a very well planned strategy and a lot of hard work and belief in one’e abilities and not overconfidence.Mixing personal with professional. We all go through tough phases in life. But if you let it affect your preparation you are doomed. So one needs to be able to separate personal from professional.Choosing popular optionals. I took Geo and Pub Ad. Got butchered in 2012. Whereas a friend of mine took Physics and Maithili and became an IAS in 2012 (I had more marks than him in Interview and Essay and similar marks in GS). I am not saying that one should not take these optionals, but be ready for getting lower average marks than other not so popular optionals say Economics.Not making notes. Notes are absolutely necessary for revision and retaining information. So unless you have eidetic memory like Sherlock you’d be better off making notes.Only reading and not revising. Biggest mistake one can make. Because after a certain time information evaporates from the mind unless you revise it. So always revise at regular intervals.Unbalanced preparation. Focusing on one area at the cost of others. Cost me my 2015 attempt as I didn’t focus on CA properly.There can be many other aspects that may bring you down. All you need to do is to be dedicated, hard working and have a well planned strategy for preparation. And avoid the mistakes others have made and you should be able to clear this exam in the very first attempt. Note: I will update this answer if I come up with new ideas. Stay tuned.

If anyone wants to crack UPSC CSE in any circumstances than s/he must know the following “CIVIL SERVICES OFFICERS”. N. Ambika- IPS officer (Must must read)- She got married at the age of 14 and blessed with two children at 18.Rakesh Sharma, AIR608 CSE2019- Visually impaired.Sparsh Gupta, AIR562 CSE 2018- Visually ImpairedAnu Kumari, AIR2 CSE2017- Mother of a 4year old childNo Amount of impediment can stop you and if there is any than it's only and only you are yourself. Now let's talk about those so-called circumstances one by one:- Family's responsibility factor:- Some of you are arguing that you have to consider family responsibilities due to some exceptional reasons at the same time when you are preparing for CSE. My friend always remember, problems are the part of life and problems will come sometimes in greater intensity while sometimes in lesser. All you need to enjoy the journey and tackle those problems with your full enthusiasm. Always remember God gives problems to those on whom he has trust that this guy will overcome with this difficulty and make a differences in society.Make Study a 'Habit':- If you succeeded in making study a Habit than believe me no one can stop you from wining. For this you just need to think. For example, if you are a working professional and you are also aspiring IAS than once a day while you are in your office surely started feeling tired than you Will definitely Start imagining that you have to study after the office. While such a thought strike in your mind just indulge yourself in anyother activity and diverte your mind. And than after your office take a rest a suddenly start studying without thinking anything. Do this for 25–30 days I know it's hard but if you did believe me Study will definitely become your habit.There is no IDEAL timetable:- Discipline is the first Buzzword in CSE preparation. So you need a timetable. But always remember obeying timetable differ P2P. I know Tina Dabi, AIR1, CSE 2015 once in an interview she claimed that she used to make timetable for next 4 to 5 months, on the other side I know some Toppers who makes timetable which they called TARGET OF THE DAY and they tried to follow it. Remember covering 80–85% of your timetable or target is enough. I'm mentioning this because some peoples have the view that timetable means only making Row and column and writing subjects day wise. No it's totally a myth, just set target for a day but it should be realistic never committ that you will cover 15chapters of Spectrum because it will be completely unrealistic, and try to cover it and if you are covering 80–85% only than it's enough for CSE preparation.Develop CSE-friendly Attitude:- Minal Karanwal, AIR35 CSE2019. Once in an interview she remarked that She failed in her previous attempt just because of her attitude towards CSE, despite one year of good preparation with enough completion of syllabus. So by CSE-Friendly I mean that neither you should take CSE lightly as post of an IAS can be for aspirant who had ordinary background in academics but not for ordinary thinking, nor you should take CSE as world's toughest exam because with this attitude you will never be able to clear it. Remember UPSC is a Process not just merely an exam.Make a habit of Smart work:- You can take thousands of example every year. Every year there are too many aspirant who are preparing hard from there 1st of their graduation but still failed to crack CSE even in 2 or 3 attempts on the other hand every year hundreds of seats were secured by engineers especially IITians this is just because of their smartness towards tackling the the most difficult part of any exam i.e. It's syllabus. This proved that UPSC wants aspirants who are smart workers instead of Hard worker.So with these technique and with consistency+dedication and smart work you can also be in the list of CSE topper's.

Starting the engine: First of all read the entire syllabus of examination thoroughly. Understand the difference and similarities between the syllabus of prelims and mains. Then go through the previous year question papers (pre+mains). Do not just start reading books without going through this process. It is important because it will keep you in the right track. The syllabus of this examination is huge so you cannot afford to read irrelevant stuff. The 1st gear: Now the first book you need to read is the NCERT. NCERTs will cover almost all the basic concepts of most of the subjects. Read NCERTs from class 6 to 12. Sometimes the UPSC asks questions directly from these books that is why do not ignore them (unless you don't have much time). NCERTs you should read:- History; Geogreaphy; Polity (class 6–12) Economics (class 9–12) Art & Culture; Sociology (class 11–12) Science (class 6–10) Biology (selected chapters of class 11–12) For History you can also consider the Tamil Nadu board books (class 11 & 12). They are also very good. The 2nd gear: Now along with NCERTs start reading a daily newspaper. This is one of the most important thing you have to do for your preparation. You can read either one of The Hindu or The Indian Express. Do not read any other. Make newspaper a daily habit. You'll need to make notes out of it but don't try to do that for the first couple of weeks. Firstly you have to learn how to read the newspaper. Not all the information and news printed is important. The good understanding of syllabus and nature of questions asked in previous year examination will help you out here. Political news might not be important but the Constitutional provisions behind it will be. For example what happened between BJP and PDP in J&K is not important but the Constitutional provisions for J&K is. Similarly what the leaders of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu are saying over the Cauvery river dispute is not important but the provisions for the inter-state water dispute, the power of supreme Court in the subject, the position of fundamental rights is. Here even the geographical position and features of the Cauvery river is important. So first of all learn to read the newspaper then move on to make notes. Another thing is that don't ignore the editorials. They are of extreme importance. They give you the facts as well as the a perspective to understand the matter. But there will be some articles from a particular point of view (right or left). You don't have to make your mindset in either way. Learn to stay neutral because that is what UPSC tests out of a candidate. Now this entire process of reading newspaper and on later times making notes out of it will consume so much time but don't worry about it because as you'll progress it will reduce. Note: Do not start reading NCERTs and newspaper as relevant only to prelims rather start with the mains syllabus then go to the prelims. You'll notice that most of the prelims syllabus is already been covered under mains. The 3rd gear: Now your next step would be to choose and cover your optional subject. Optional is extremely important because it carries 500 marks in the mains examination. Scoring good in optional not only ensures your selection but also improves your rank. Choose your optional carefully. Short list the subjects you are comfortable with and then go through the syllabus and previous year question papers and then decide the one. Then quickly plan and finish the entire syllabus. Read according to the nature of questions asked. The 4th gear: Along with the optional start preparing for the GS. Now it's time to go through the reference books. Start with a subject at a time or multiple (do the way you are more comfortable with). Make notes because they will help you for revising quickly. It's important to make your own notes instead of copying or borrowing or buying from outside because by making notes yourself you will learn and remember for longer time. Again making good quality notes need practice and good understanding of syllabus and questions being asked. (That is why the first step is crucial). Note: Learning and remembering are equally important because if you have learned everything precisely but can't recall them when sitting in the exam hall, then the learning is of no use. Regular revision helps you to remember longer and good notes provides quality revision. In the meantime learn the technique of answer writing and practice regularly because your answer will be the only way to present your knowledge. Understand the difference between the keyword like comment; elucidate; elaborate; discuss; critize etc… being asked in the exam. You can also join any online test series to test yourself. Also do not ignore the essay paper. Write an essay every week or in every ten days. Keep the time limit in mind. You'll be asked to write 2 essays of word limit 1000–1200 in three hours. Also collect the important quotes and lines which you can use in your essays. The 5th gear: Now 3–4 months before the prelims start preparing solely for it. Go more for the factual information both in current and in the static part but don't ignore the conceptual information all together because UPSC do ask questions requiring conceptual knowledge in prelims too. Take mock tests and try to solve as many MCQs as you can. Also solve the previous years prelims question papers religiously. Sometimes UPSC do repeat the questions. Also learn the elimination method to solve the questions of which you do not know the answer accurately. Also read from the additional important sources like yojana, economic survey; watch debates on rajya Sabha tv; any important blog on internet etc… Revision is the key in this examination. Read-Revise-Repeat that is the process. Revise each topic as much as you can. Also do not take too much pressure of the examination. Do not compare yourself with others. Always maintain a good confidence. A good confidence gives you a good memory to recall things when you need them. Even in the exam hall if you do not know the answer of any particular question do not panic. Try to solve it with the knowledge you gained throughout your preparation. Keep yourself balance in these 5 gears and soon you'll be shifting to the 6th gear which will be the training program in LBSNAA. BEST OF LUCK… PEACE

Hi everyone, It's great to hear “First attempt” always .It resonates with the thoughts of an adolescent girl /boy who says I want to be a one woman man or a one man woman .The firsts are always so special ,whether it be a relationship or a job or UPSC attempt .We always put the best efforts in the first go ,after which there's just filling up the gaps (emotionally as well as mentally).But in UPSC it's a bit different ,as in each attempt you get to know your weakness in various areas .So never judge a person with the number of attempts he took to clear the exam .Let's be real , there's a lot of luck factor playing role in the exam.Wait ,I am not saying that it is the only factor but yes a significant one ,alonv with other .There are a lot of factors like vacancies ,cut off ,kind of paper etc etc ,infact quite a dynamic situation.I have an example for it ,some of the top rankers marginally clear the prelims and some of the best brains marginally cannot clear the prelims .Infact I missed the prelims by 0.33marks in 2015 and cleared it by 1.6 marks in 2016 and by 10 marks in 2018 .Infact when you write the mains you can never be sure that you ll get an interview call or not .I got 140 marks in essay although I never expected because in my test series I always got 100 or 105(although my peer group and mentor, who reviewed my essay was constantly telling me that I would get more than 130 ).Also if some of you might have read my answer to Nitisha Gupta's answer to How was your interview for the UPSC CSE, and how many marks did you get? you will be convinced about the uncertainty involved .So UPSC is altogether a different ball game !My sincere appeal to all of you is just treat all your attempt as the first one .Give your entire energy ,focus ,hard work and concentration in whichever attempt you are giving .You never know when would everything fall just in line and your efforts will be rewarded .So coming back to the question (after all this I hope the first attempt pshycology is a bit suppressed )which is now only left to how to crack UPSC CSE under any circumstances ? Something about me that you may find relevant :I was in probation in Indian Railways during 2016 and out of touch from UPSC studies since September 2015 ,when I decided to appear for one more time in 2016 (I made up my mind for the second attempt in April 2016 ).I was very nervous because my probation was coming to an end soon, also pressure of departmental exams and most importantly had not touched the books for the past 7–8 months .But I donno where did I get the courage to even give it a start .I mean it was against all odds .See sometimes it's not only the financial problem (I am lucky that never had one),but a mix of personal life as well as professional life ,stepping out of your comfort zone ,fear of uncertainty and above all inertia .I won't lie I had all except for the financial one . Challenges lying ahead were : Time:Had no idea about how will I manage time .Also I had wasted around 7–8 months in just enjoying my probation period. In railways during probation we are literally on Bharat darshan for almost 30 week (field trainings from North to South ,East to West ). Railway probation:My classroom course was about to begin from April 8th 2016 to June 2nd 2016 on the remotest location in India (Jamalpur ,Bihar ),which meant classes from 9 to 5 followed by weekly tests (every Friday we had a test the marks of which were to be added to our UPSC marks to make a seniority list ). Resources :Obviously since we were continuously travelling so I did not have my books with me and other resources .I need a real book as I underline and read ,thats my habit (may be you call it bad).I don't make notes for anything just read a number of times . No peer group :I was the only female officer trainee in my batch so it was kind of difficult for me .Of course all were friends but I was honestly not very comfortable because I had never been with my batchmates before .So there was some kind of emotional inertia . Insecurities:This was the worst part specially when you don't have anyone to talk about it .Sometimes when my studies were on track , suddenly a fear would haunt me regarding whether my approach was apt (especially when I had once failed to clear prelims in 2015 ),whether my sources were good enough ,whether I was giving appropriate time ,what would full time preparers be actually doing in Delhi when I m stuck here in this hell where internet is a luxury .I haven't given any tests.How do I go about making a plan and schedule which could help me in revision ,infact what should I revise at the last moment before exams .Now I know for real that all of us have it since I have started personally mentoring aspirants on Askthetopper platform . Others included :What if I clear prelims ,how will I go about mains ,is there sufficient time ,who will evaluate my answers ,I have never actually written an essay after class 10th so how will I write one now.(I had already gone through toppers videos on 2015 so I couldn't find them very useful for me because each one had a different story to tell and no one was evaluating the essays ). I think all of you must have been going through these thoughts (around 60% same ).So dear aspirants do not panic .There will never be a perfect time in your life .Life is just like a chemical equilibrium kind of thing .It tries to come to equilibrium and we are the catalysts.Sometimes here ,sometimes there and only rarest of rare times at equilibrium .So just try to achieve your goals in the present situation .It may be bad but certainly not permanent .Also of late we have started living in a world where there are a lot of insecurities so for people who have everything they are worried about what will happen when they don't have it .We have actually forgotten to live in the moment for real .Many ask about IRMS about prelims being postponed ,I know it bothers you but you can't think about something which is not real . So don't try to change the circumstances,adapt yourself to them. Just do your work honestly . Coming back to how to crack UPSC :You will find a million of answers to this question and some are really very good ,but I can tell you only my strategy and what sailed me through : 1.Hard Work :I really did :honest hard work .And mind you it does not mean that others don't but as I say God has been kind to bless me with that some % of luck required to crack this exam.Also I never made notes and hence hard work is = notes making .I intially feared to start because I was out of touch and was in a comfort zone . 2.Belief :I believed in myself as well as my mentor .If you don't believe in yourself half the battle is lost .Just believe that “You can do it”.Ypu need to trust ypur mentor or any person whose guiding you in this journey .Until you don't believe in him/her you will waste time running around unnecessary things .Be positive and optimistic always . 3.Mentor :You should definitely have one .Caution :THIS DOESN'T MEAN THAT YOU CANNOT CLEAR UPSC WITHOUT A MENTOR .But without one your journey might take a bit longer .Now how to get a mentor is a different story altogether (I will write about it if I get a question since I don't own a space on Quora ).I felt so much relieved when I had some selected person to guide me and help me out with all my insecurities and I owe my sucess to him .Of course hard work has no substitute but even a donkey works hard so my point is that your force * displacement should be equal to work done .So a mentor will help you channelise your hard work and energy towards your goal. 4.I am not a perfectionist attitude : Understand the exam .It's an exam to recruit people for general administration so you need to have an idea of everything and a bit of extra knowledge in some areas .Had it been such an in depth test then it would have been something like Engineering servies ,Economic services etc .Some IRS officers are doctors ,some are literature graduates and once we land into the academy we are injected with law ,accounts ,income tax Act which are totally new for almost all of us .See you don't have to do PhD.Somepeople suggest books like “How does the elephant dance “for IR ,I mean who cares about the dance of an elephant .So just see what is important and relevant (this is the time you need a mentor ) 5.There's nothing such as Parampara ,Pratishtha but yes Anushashan (No Tradition ,Reputation but yes Discipline ): No please don't follow any rituals and customes blindly unless you are comfortable .By this I mean some “Must do” things like newspaper reading ,notes making ,test series ,etc etc (All of us know these as we all belong to the same zoo).See just do what has been your habit as far as notes making is concerned .Also you can go through my Quora answer for newspaper notes making Nitisha Gupta's answer to Can we read the newspaper for the UPSC CSE daily but make notes from the analysis available online at various sites? 6.Honesty:There is nothing in this world that you chase withour honesty and you get it .Even to earn black money you habe to work honestly .This is a virtue which is desired out of every public servant and so an exam which is meant to select candidates or for that matters any exam will require the aspirants to be honest .Honest with themselves ,honest with their time and preparation ,honest with their hard work .See we are adults and no one is monitoring us so we get indulged in some undesirable activities for fun sake ,it's here that we start cheating on ourselves and our precious time and energy .Please avoid this .There are temptations ,hormonal outbursts ,emtional peaks but don't waste time and be honest about your time utilisation .You know in your heart what were you thinking when you had a book open in front of you .So don't let that happen . 7.Others :a)Don't panic it leads you nowhere b)Eat healthy as well as drink healthy .Drink lots of water . c)Make a schedule and follow it d) Reach out to someone (mentor may be ) when you feel low and discuss it . e) Try mediation for 10–15 minutes that will enhance your concentration and make you calm and composed f) Don't waste your time on social media ,they are disgusting as they project the false happiness of people . Most importantly stay happy because UPSC is not life ,it's just a very small part of your life ,be clear that also the journey of UPSC because results are just bursts of happiness they don't last long . Soon I will be taking a session on “How to start answer writing from a scratch “ for those who find it tough initially as to how should one begin .Also monthly current affairs session will be held on WebEx where the magazine will be discussed and relevant portions will be told along with linking them to static as well as mains preparation.For registration please Whatsapp on 8240649834 or mail at askthetopper@gmail.com. Best wishes 🙂

Well, I have passed the examination in my first attempt and I have done it immediately after completing my clg in May 2018.So,I think my experience would be helpful to you. I started to attend coaching classes of vajiram and ravi in my 3rd year of engineering and my CGPA at that time was 6.8.Now I had to travel 2 hours daily ,spend 2.5 hours in coaching classes and return back to my college.All I wanted was to attend classes religiously and at the same time ,I wanted to make sure my CGPA reached 7(which is a difficult task in 3rd year and that too with coaching and all) Since I began my preparation ,things began to chance.Due to lack of time ,I started to plan things.Before going to coaching ,I never attended my class in IIT on time,I used to use my mobile in cls and me listening to cls was a rare thing. But slowly time came to be very precious and I had to change all of these habits in my college.For UPSC , I used to complete my newspaper reading while I was tarvelling and waiting in long queues at Vajiram.I literally ran for time and tried to use every bit of it(Labs -used to complete them before time and leave for coaching ,as most of the labs were used to complete around 5 and my coaching starts at 5. Classes- whenever a boring class was there ,I used to carry my upsc books.Traveling - I remeber all those bus journeys,metro rides and airports where I sat alone and read ) Things didnt change overnight.The first examination I faced in my clg after joining coaching ,I did very badly and if I performed in that way my CGPA would have reached 5.0.But I thought I should give it some more time and it is then things started slowly to change and by end of 4 th year 2nd sememster ,January 2018 I ended up getting CGPA 7.56(CGPA hardly changes after that).When I thought things were going in my way ,2018 had completely different thing for me. I hit a lowest point in my personal life .I felt like something has crushed my dignity and was feeling vulnerable, sad,angry.Added to this ,my college was getting completed in may and for past 2 years I burnt all the time in library.This added fuel to fire and there were different things going in my mind.I wanted to be with friends for atleast the last few days ,but i couldnt as I had prelims in june. I left college in april without even attending for my departmental photograph.I missed hostel day,placement parties of my friends and everything, and landed up in a apartment in hyderabad. This phase of 6 months (APRIL -OCTOBER 2018) was the hardest phase in my life.I was not in a position to enjoy anything in my life and I started to read for all the time I have, so that I will not be thinking about all these things. I rarely came out of my home and for 3 months (after prelims )I read like hell.I rarely used to talk with anyone (even my family).Added to this one day things went beyond my control. The moment my phn had 8 missed call ,I knew something was wrong.I received a msg that my friend has died in a accident.All I could do was to cry in break time and do my studing as usually.This was the most difficult thing i have done.To tell yourself that everything is okay and do your duty and then go back in break time and feel the pain. I made my life so miserable those 6 months that UPSC became a more than a exam for me.Sitting for those long hours per day I grew my weight which I used to feel while walking.Those 6 months I used to daily dream of the day when I would get a oppurtunity to lead a normal life I dont know the above things worked or not.In my testseries I never completed the whole paper(used to do 17 -18 questions) and I never practiced writing 2 papers per day. But the day I went for mains ,I was not nervous.I was waiting for it.I was hungry for a performance.I completed all questions in all papers which I wasnt able to do in test series.I qualified mains and received a call for interview. The day results came ,nothing was unusaul.I went to library in the morning ,came home for lunch and then left for tennis at 5 pm.When my result came out i was playing tennis and it was my mother who told my result .I secured 699 rank at age of 22. I went to play tennis even though i knew results were coming that evening.It was not because I was confident.It was only because I was okay with both the things i..e being in the list and out of the list.Today I am more balanced as a person and have huge respect for time .So I just concentrate on things that I plan for the day and I stopped worrying about things that were not in my control. Now coming to part of under anycircumstances.I mentioned u above what i had to face and there are many people who faced more than this for clearing this exam. But one truth that I learnt after all this process is that humans have a layered personality.I couldnt have done anything I said above if I just wept with pain or found solace in others . I was pushed to such a extreme were I had to break my comfort layers and explore strength within me .I had to dig deeper within me so that I can stand for something that I dreamt. I thought ,I was stronger when I was with my people.I was wrong.I was stronger when I fought it all alone.I thought I was happy when I had everything in life.But believe me , that sense of happiness that one gets, when we know that we have fought for everything and witheld whatever came our way ,is one such feeling that we can bet our life on So u need only one thing to cross this exam in 1 st attempt.That is more of you .In any of the attempt I think only thing that can make a difference is you. As you have mentioned crossing exam under any circumstances I have written this .But if you were looking for strategy i am sorry . Hope this helps.

I am in a good position to answer this, not because I have cracked the exam in my first attempt. But because I have improved over the last 5 years by learning from the mistakes I made. I always wonder how some people are able to crack the exam in first attempt while others are taking 4,5 or 6 attempts - even though both are of same intelligence. What I realized is that most aspirants who have cracked it in their first attempt have guidance. Either their brother/sister has already cleared the exam or their parents are civil servants or they have really strong contacts who can guide them. Because first 1–2 years of the aspirant goes in figuring out how this process works, what should be the strategy etc. People who figure out on their own like me make mistakes, learn from it and improve, And hence they take more attempts. But even if you don’t know anyone who can guide, I believe I can help you with this answer. Since, it is difficult to give detailed strategy as to how to prepare as every individual has their unique journey…I will try to broadly give an outline as to how to crack it in First Attempt. The Magic Strategy Be with senior aspirant who have at least given mains. If you are going to Delhi, Bangalore, Hyderabad etc for UPSC preparation — preferably be roommates with serious senior aspirants.If you are having basic intelligence and can read on your own, please don’t join any foundation course (if your age is greater than 21, else it is better to join a foundation course). Instead join a good mains test series.Give the year long mains test series very seriously and religiously. Follow the schedule strictly. You will cover most of the topics in this test series itself.Simultaneously go for optional classes. If your optional classes are completed before November. Revise the syllabus in 1 or 2 months.From January or February, start your prelims preparation.Start your prelims preparation with basic books and current affairs.Stop mains preparation 3 months before prelims and focus only on prelims.Attend one test series from a reputed institute and buy other institutes test series from market.For the last 3 months, attempt one test everyday. Don’t worry about marks. Focus on learning from mistakes made while solving MCQ’s.If you follow this you are most likely to clear prelims and compete with your roommates who have already spent 3–4 years in preparation.After prelims, immediately revise your optional in 15 days and join an optional test series.While filling Detailed Application Form(DAF), take guidance from people who have scored high marks in interview as the direction in which interview goes depends on you DAF.Do extensive answer writing practice with your friends.After your mains, start your preparation for interview. Keep in mind that interview is not a test of your knowledge, but test of your personality. So practice being confident, honest, calm and level headed…rather than reading extensively.All the best.

Personally, it took me two years to come on the final list. However, I still believe that cracking UPSC in the first attempt is very much possible. Some of the brightest officers like Tina Dabi, Roman Saini, Anmol Singh Bedi etc have all shown us that not only can one aim to come on the final list in their first attempt but also one can aim to be the topper of the batch. My journey extended to a couple of years, as I made a few mistakes and took a little more time to understand what the exam demands. After deep introspection I would like to make the following suggestions to answer your question: Choose your optional wisely I gave my first attempt right out of college. I was a fresh graduate in mechanical engineering and I felt that I should take Mechanical as my optional as I was in touch with the subject. However, I eventually found it to be too bulky to revise during the three month period between pre and mains. So In my next attempt I switched to anthropology. I really enjoyed studying it and could also give time to GS papers.Keep your material concise the key is to study optimally and revise content again and again! Please chose the basic books- NCERTs etc. If you are consulting multiple books, make notes so that you have everything at one place.Focus on your optional right from the beginning so if you have one year to your prelims, finish your optional in first few months itself. 3 months before prelims, focus should only be on the prelims.Write answers regularly I wrote one answer everyday and one essay per month. Answer writing practice for optional is also very important. I regularly submitted answers to my teachers and took their feedback.Be very thorough with current affairs Read Indian Express/ The Hindu regularly. Try to form opinions about issues.Take your classes seriously Now that I look back, it sounds very geeky but I always sat on the first row in every class. I never sat with friends. I attended all my classes regularly And revised what was taught everyday. I felt lucky that I could go to classes. Not everyone can afford to stay in Delhi and prepare. So this kept me excited !Having said that, I would like to say that success comes to you when you are truly ready, just at the right time. Give every attempt like it's your first. Please understand that its a challenging exam and do not get disheartened if it takes more time than you anticipated. All the best!

You can’t. Sorry for being brutal, but you cannot crack UPSC CSE in the first attempt in ANY CIRCUMSTANCE. You have to create yourself such a circumstance. Firstly, be aware that many things have to be aligned(may be, that is what elders call it alignment of the stars) in order to crack this exam in the first attempt. Check out some superstitions regarding to stars alignment: 10 Superstitions About Stars  The Cancer constellation has supposedly helped farmers predict rain. If you see most of the aspirants who have cracked it in their first attempt, there is a backstory to their success. They might have had guidance from their family members or they might have been extremely intelligent or they somehow got the right strategy through proper guidance of a bureaucrat or they might have started their preparation during their graduation itself. Don’t be over superstitious about the alignments. It is necessary that you make sure your preparation and opportunity is aligned. Success happens when the preparation meets opportunity. But, neither does everyone has the same privilege nor the same circumstances. So, it is you who have to create the circumstances which helps you in cracking the exam in the first attempt itself. Here is our advice to create such circumstances: Choosing the right optional: Many aspirants make the mistake of choosing an optional based on trends or previous year marking patterns. They choose a completely new subject as their optional. Then they go for optional classes along with GS classes and hence don’t have time to read neither. This is the major reason many people fail mains in their first attempt even if they clear prelims. Optional has very high weightage as one can score more than 300 out of 500 in optionals. If you are in final year of your graduation, please focus on your graduation subject instead of focusing on GS foundation course or anything else. People who have chosen this strategy have repeatedly succeeded. For example, in CSE 2015, Tina Dabi scored 299 in Political Science (her graduation subject) when others have struggled to score even 250 in their optionals. Similarly in CSE 2016, Avdhesh Meena scored 356 in his civil engineering optional (he scored 213 in Civil eng. Optional Paper 1 alone) which was his graduation subject. Your graduation subjects are your assets. Leverage them to score extraordinary marks in UPSC CSE mains.  Choosing the right institute: Most aspirants go to some coaching institute and think their job is done. But apart from teaching, the aspirants should be able to get guidance from the faculty. Aspirants who have cleared it in their first attempt have had the privilege of guidance from a elder brother/sister or bureaucrat parents/relatives etc. Not everyone is blessed with having such guidance. So, choose an institute where it can impart quality classes you can also get quality guidance. The faculty members should be able to guide you like an elder brother/sister. They should be invested in your well being and success. Choosing a healthy lifestyle: Many aspirants wrongly think of UPSC as a penance and that one should sacrifice food, sleep, comfort to clear the exam. This is a wrong strategy. You cannot clear the exam if you fall sick. Students who don’t take care of their health won’t be able to give their 100 % for their preparation. Especially, students who come to Delhi for coaching tend to eat any food outside,sleep very less and consequently suffer from bad health and patchy preparation. Having a healthy lifestyle is another circumstance that one should create. Choosing the right peer group: Aspirants should choose a peer group who are working with the same level of motivation to clear the exam in first attempt. Each member of the peer group should help each other and compete with each other to perform well in this exam. Choosing the right test series: one should test their skills at regular intervals. Many first time aspirants have this feeling that they will join a test series after completing the syllabus. But it will be too late by the time the coaching institutes complete the syllabus. Don’t wait till end to take practise tests. Apart from prelims tests, write mains tests too. Optional test series should be completed at least 3 months before prelims. This will give a feel for the exam and you won’t be overwhelmed towards the end. Be confident, not overconfident or underconfident: We have seen aspirants who are either under confident or over confident. Neither is the right way. If you are putting in right efforts and preparing under right guidance, have confidence in your strategy. Confidence plays a key role during your preparation. If you are under confident, you will spend more time worrying than in preparing. If you are overconfident, you won’t be receptive to any feedback or guidance. We have seen some students who have talked to some top 10 ranker and feel confident that if they prepare the same way as him they will be able to clear it. They forget that the suggestions from the top 10 ranker are based on his individual circumstances and his experience. This strategy might not work for everyone. Be aware of current happenings: The weightage of current affairs has increased in both prelims and mains. Aspirants should focus on current affairs along with static part. We hope that you will create the circumstances that will allow you to crack the exam in first attempt. Choose wisely. P.S. Other tips that will help you in clearing the exam in first attempt: Attitude required to clear the exam in first attempt. Habits that help in UPSC CSE preparation. How to study Geography? How to study Polity? How to study government schemes? How to choose editorials? How to improve answer writing skills? All the best.

I really liked this question as I started my CSE preparation with the same mindset and by God's grace I cleared the exam in my first attempt. Coming to the question, few suggestions from my end would be: - Cut to the chaseFirst of all it's really important I feel that when aspirants begin their preparation it should be with the attitude that their first attempt should be their best and only attempt (at least till the final result is out post which your decision may change). I say this because once you feel that you have only one shot at CSE, you will tend to study with more efficiency than you could ever study had you been complacent thinking about the number of attempts. You may have heard this before that CSE is a test more of your attitude than aptitude. - Not just an exam It is equally important that you not treat UPSC CSE as just an exam. It is so much more than that. You must treat it as a devotional exercise - something that you not only give your heart and soul to but something that is profoundly sacred to you and hence you are willing to work hard not just as an aspirant but as a devotee who would not give in to distractions of any kind because what they've set their heart on is too holy and pious to be ignored for anything else. - Means to an endWhat makes UPSC CSE larger than life is not the glory of having cleared the exam but that of getting a platform to revel in true public service. I still choose to believe this is the only purpose with which one should want to prepare for this exam. Why it is all the more important is that during your days of doubts and despair, only this clarity will help you not to lose your mind. You will need to keep reminding yourself as to why you wanted to prepare for this exam in the first place. Once you realize that the exam is not an end but a means to an end, trust me your approach to studies will change and change for the good. That motivation will be your strongest weapon with which you shall enter the battlefield. It will also be the lighthouse that guides you in uncharted territory and helps you reach the shore safely. - 'Great achievement is born of great sacrifice'I couldn't agree more with this statement having had to do this myself. Greatness that comes not just with clearing the exam but with the work you do after that, requires some sacrifice. Your willingness and readiness to do so will be the deciding factor in your tryst with UPSC. These sacrifices can be big and small, the smalls ones may include giving up on your social life temporarily, etc and the big ones may include giving up on a job or better career prospects despite financial problems, etc. In my case it went as far as compromising with my health which of course is not advisable. But the underlying message is that you must be prepared to make sacrifices as is expected of a true devotee. This is important if you want to clear the exam in your first attempt itself. - A healthy mind rests in a healthy body and vice versa I think I don't need to elaborate much on this as it is pretty scientific. If you're not healthy, your efficiency levels will certainly drop. Considering that the preparation makes your lifestyle quite sedentary, it is important that you find time to pursue some activity that you may enjoy and it is equally important to maintain a healthy mind through meditation or any other practice that helps you maintain your cool. Your most important asset for clearing this exam is your body and mind and hence it is but logical to protect them and keep nurturing them. - When life gives you lemons, you know what to do! I think once you are able to develop the kind of mindset as illustrated in the above points, other practical considerations like minimizing your distractions, preparation of a study plan, maintaining consistency, etc. will come naturally to you. I say this with my own experience. Your inner drive will help you find solutions to problems and help you improvise. To give you an example, when I was not well enough to write tests for Mains, I made my sister write them for me while I was dictating the answers. That way even though I couldn't test my speed but at least I got my thought process evaluated. What I'm trying to suggest is that a lot of problems will come your way. It is important to not lose hope at such times and improvise. This will too come naturally when you take care of everything that has been said above. Having said all this, I truly believe that aspirants should first assess their motive behind leaving everything else to sit for this exam. If your purpose can be served by an alternate career path, then you can refrain from investing so much in CSE as this exam is highly unpredictable. And for those who can relate to everything I said above, my best wishes to you in your endeavors which I know will eventually be for the good of the society.

By god’s grace I could crack civil services exam in my First Attempt , but before the results, I was very SKEPTICAL about clearing it. It was because we as an aspiration have been repeatedly told about the difficulty level of the exam. So I was not sure that I was prepared completely and had that feeling of inadequacy. I always thought that aspirant those who clear this exam are much more intelligent and laborious (as if they come from Mars) Howsoever I realised that it is usual people like you and me who can crack this exam with the Right Strategy. There are numerous CRISIS which a aspirant can face during the course of preparation- UNDER ESTIMATION of one’s own capabilities and over estimation of others.Unable to focus and avoid various types of DISTRACTIONS at this age.A sense of ‘Unsettledness’ when your friends are earning in lakhs and getting promoted and ‘settled’ in their professions while you roam around the streets of old Rajinder nagar or mukharjee nagar ,collecting photocopied notes.Prolonged process of preparation and examination leads to numerous phases of DEPRESSION like conditions.Now the solution to these problems/crisis may vary from person to person depending upon their nature and circumstances. But I would like to share my own experience. I come from a very humble background with normal educational qualification. Before I started my preparation for civil services I cleared GATE and got placement . I risked them both to fulfill my childhood dream. So the STRATEGIES which I followed are- First thing I did was to stop thinking about lost opportunities ( like M.tech and job) and rather focus myself on one goal (i.e to clear civil services)Building a strong FOUNDATION on few and basic books and revising then repeatedly.I devised my preparation PLAN and time management plan according to the nature and demand of various stages of the exam. For eg for prelims reading basic books (from factual perspective),reading newspapers and magazines ( keeping in mind the types of questions being asked in past years)I DIVIDED my day into 3 clear cut segments ,out of which 2 were intensive.I selectively used social media ( deactivated Facebook account) and restricted mobile phone usage.I used to religiously follow TEST SERIES and evaluate my performance seriously so as to have regular assessment of my preparation and improve my performance.Certain OTHER THINGS to remember- Do hard work and try to be confident.“Nothing works without working ” so be consistent in your approach.Be in a good company ( choose them wisely,as it can play a vital role in shaping your future)As Milo’s story says,( Must readHow to Build Muscle: Strength Lessons from Milo of Croton) practice according to your capability and believe in yourself rather copying others. All the very best.

By inculcating these 10 habits: 1. PLANNING This begins with a careful study of the entire syllabus, a brief look at the previous year’s questions papers and, if possible, a direct interaction with someone who has seen the exam from close quarters. Use the insights you get from there to decide: - which optional to choose. - whether you should join any classes or study on your own. - which books/notes/websites/magazines you should consult. - how you will allocate your time to ensure that you are satisfactorily prepared for each of the three stages. 2. DISCIPLINE Once you have prepared a broad plan, stick to it as far as possible. Minor aberrations are unavoidable but, on the whole, you should be able to meet your weekly and monthly targets consistently. Remember that every missed deadline adds pressure and increases the workload, severely jeopardising your future plans too. 3. SELF-BELIEF This exam is an endless chaos of options and opinions. Almost every person will have something to say that may raise doubts or fears regarding whether you are proceeding in the correct direction or not. Plus, there is an information overload in terms of the availability of material, teachers and classes. Therefore, develop belief in yourself and unwavering faith in your decision. Don’t be hasty, take well-informed decisions. And once you have taken them, don’t go back on them. Remember that nobody can take a perfect decision-some of your decisions will have flaws too. But then, even a topper scores less than 60% in this exam. So don’t waste time thinking and rethinking what you should do. A mind troubled by doubts cannot focus on the course to victory. 4. INTROSPECTION Everyone has weaknesses, very few admit and rectify them. Assess what the exam demands, be honest with yourself and identify the qualities/abilities you lack. It may be memorization, communication, command over the language, answer presentation etc. And work hard on developing them. (There was this student of mine who, in the few minutes before the class started, would practice writing alphabets on rough sheets to improve his handwriting) 5. HARD WORK Don’t fall for the myth of “smart work”. This exam requires back-breaking labour, sacrifice and patience. Too many aspirants try to save themselves from this labour by searching for shortcuts, only to realise much later that those shortcuts just don’t exist. If you have a doubt about whether or not something is important, it probably is- do it. It will equip you better to deal with the challenges of this exam, in ways you can’t even anticipate. 6. CONCENTRATION This is an absolute must, whether it is while reading the daily newspaper, attending a class or making notes. Aspirants often forget that the exam is not just about reading. It is about reading with understanding, acquiring conceptual clarity, organising the material methodically and developing the ability to reproduce the content upon demand. And none of this is possible unless you block the world out and concentrate when you study. 7. READING For an aspirant who wants to clear the exam in the very first attempt, an average study day would require atleast 8 hours of reading. Thus, one single study session should be atleast 2-3 hours long. More importantly, the reading should be such that a revision of the same material becomes significantly easier. Some simple tips here include: - start small, say with one-hour long study sessions and gradually increase them. - underline and highlight while you read. - make notes on loose sheets, which will allow you to add more information on the same issue at a later date too. - leave a margin on the right side of the sheet, where you can make small summaries. This will facilitate easy revision. 8. WRITING Many aspirants make the mistake of thinking that they will practice answer-writing (which is needed only in the Mains) after the Prelims. At that time, they realise: - there is no time to make significant improvements because the syllabus coverage itself takes a lot of time. - there is no teacher/guide readily available for regular evaluation and feedback. - joining a test series helps in revising the subject but not in improving writing abilities. Most institutes return the checked answer scripts after a gap of a couple of weeks from the test date. Therefore, once you start developing reasonable command over a subject or even a topic, write some answers on questions asked in the previous year’s Mains on it-if possible, get a few answers evaluated. 9. REVISING Since this exam involves an enormous amount of material, unless you revise, most of what you learn in one week will be unlearned and forgotten in the next. Summarize, memorize and keep revising. 10. FITNESS This exam is mentally and physically demanding. Academic rigour, the pressure of competition, unending work, constant deadlines, setbacks, the cost of failure – all such factors take a toll on the mental well-being of students. To such an extent that many succumb to depression, resort to substance abuse, adopt fatalistic views on life etc. Added to this is the physical toll of long study hours, the necessity of training yourself to write without pause for upto 3 hours at a stretch, poor food and living conditions etc. A very simple way to avoid such problems is to ensure physical fitness and mental rejuvenation. Some simple tips here include: - allocate time on a daily basis for a physical activity, be it running, yoga, badminton- anything that is feasible for you. - allow yourself regular breaks for entertainment and relaxation, be it time spent with family and friends, going for a movie, celebrating a birthday/festival etc. - eat healthy and avoid foods that make you sluggish or lethargic. - a sound sleep is absolutely essential to rest our vital organs and enable them to function at peak efficiency the next day.
