Have you heard of Anupama Anjali? She is an IAS officer (CSE 2017) It took her 2 years to be on the final list. However, I still believe that cracking UPSC Exam in the 1st attempt is very much possible. Some of the brightest officers like Tina Dabi, Roman Saini, Anmol Singh Bedi and many others have shown us that not only can one aim to be in the final list in their first attempt but also can become the topper of the batch. Anupama’s journey extended to a couple of years, as she had made few mistakes & it took a little more time to understand what the exam demands. I would like to give following suggestions to answer your question: Choose your optional wisely She gave her first attempt right out of college. She was a fresh graduate in mechanical engineering & felt that she should take Mechanical as her optional as she was in touch with the subject. However, she eventually found it to be too bulky to revise during the three month period between prelims and mains. So In her next attempt she switched to anthropology. She really enjoyed studying it & was able to give time to GS papers.Keep your material concise the key is to study optimally & revise content again and again! Please chose the basic books like - NCERTs etc. If you are reading multiple books, do make notes so that you have everything at one place.Focus on your optional right from the beginning so if you have 1 year to your prelims, finish your optional in the first few months itself. In last 3 months before prelims, your focus should be only on the prelims.Write answers regularly: She wrote 1 answer everyday & one essay per month. Answer writing practice for optional is very important. She regularly submitted answers to her teachers & took their feedback.Be very thorough with current affairs: Read Indian Express/ The Hindu newspaper regularly. Try to form your own neutral opinions about issues.Take your classes seriously: In her coaching, she always sat on the first row in every class. She never sat with friends. She attended all her classes regularly & revised what was taught everyday. Not everyone can afford to stay in Delhi & prepare for the exam. So this kept her excited & motivated !I would say that success comes to you when you are truly ready, you have to wait for the right time. Give every attempt like it is your first. Please understand that it is a challenging exam and don’t get disheartened if it takes more time than you had anticipated. All the best! If you are preparing for UPSC, you should join our space: CrackUPSC

I have my UPSC attempt in 2023 . And to be very honest I have not started studying anything. But what I did was reading some toppers blog, watching videos and out of that devising my own strategy. I fixed my booklist, my strategy, what I will follow and what I will not, will I join coaching or not, will I prepare from Delhi or from my home?. These are the few things that I think if followed properly, one has the chance to see his name in the final list. 1.Knowing the Syllabus, it is the most important. Once you know the Syllabus, it becomes easy for you to read current affairs. Knowing Syllabus will help you differentiate between the part you should read or you should not read. Learning Syllabus is the very basic and first step. 2.Sticking to your booklist.The booklist you have decided for yourself , you must stick to that. Never get influenced by plenty of material available in ORN. Don't try copying others sources. 90 percent of the booklist is same of every aspirant. You should take care of the remaining 10 percent and you must be adamant enough to stick on that. 3.Reading the newspaper regularly, with utmost attention. Most of the questions are asked from the current affairs, in the initial stage you can take help of IASBABA, INSIGHTS ON INDIA, they provide every day summary of newspaper you can go through that to understand better. And after the end of the month covering the covering the Current affairs with any reputed coaching magazine like Vision IAS. These magazines will help you in clearing basic facts and concepts and to revise better. 4.If you are starting from June, you should definitely completely your standard books by February so that you can revise well for prelims and start practising for mocks. 5.Any UPSC aspirant can start writing answer after 3 months of preparation, it can be a huge plus point if you start writing answer from October onwards on platforms like IAS Baba or Insights. Answer writing is the key to pass through mains. 6. Solving previous year question paper so that you can see the trend of UPSC and topics which are asked the most. 7.For prelims, giving at least 60 mock papers, so that you can analyze you weakness and strength. It will help you to know that to what extent your guessing works, how much question you should attend? Giving mock papers will help you a lot. 8.For mains, covering every term given in Syllabus. You should know the meaning of every term given in Syllabus. For mains, try to not left any stone unturned.PRACTICE, PRACTICE, PRACTICE answer writing. Write sectional tests as well as full tests. Be mentally prepared to work hard! 9.Avoid social media through your preparation, avoid everything which distracts you. Don't take risk in these things. 10. To be able to resist temptation of going out, of watching TV. You should prepare yourself mentally and emotinally. You should enjoy the journey and be prepared for the gloomy days as well. 11.You should beat all the blues that come through your preparation. Be consistent, patient and hard working. 12.Use time time between Prelims exams and it's result. 13.Dont forget to focus on subject like essay and ethics. Cover everything. 14.Your optional can decide your rank, choose the option wisely, it plays a major role. 300+ in optional and you can see your name in the final list. 15 . Be confident at every stage of preparation. Trust the process. Trust your resources and hardwork. 16 Interview:- Be a real genuine person, don't brag!. Prepare DAF truthfully. And be calm!. I hope every UPSC aspirant top the list by flying colors. You can message me, if you have doubts regarding preparation!

UPSC CSE can very well ne cleared in first attempt. Those of us who fail, its because we commit some mistakes. Based upon my experience with CSE preparation , I would like to share few tips with you which might help you to clear the exam: Your main focus of preparation should be Mains. Give 3–4 months to Prelims preparation before Prelims exam.Keep a balance between GS preparation and Optional. Give adequate time to all GS papers.Do not ignore essay and ethics paper.Choose your Optional carefully as it can be a deciding factor.Do not waste your first attempt. Many people, including me, give first attempt just to get an experience. A failure at this stage, no matter how casually you have given the exam, undermines your confidence. Your first attempt is the best attempt as level of motivation is highest during that time.Do a lot of answer writing practise. Answer writing practise consists of daily answer writing and test series.Read one good newspaper religiously.If possible, try to cover Rajya Sabha Big Picture debates. They would help you to develop perspective and argumentation skills.Watch few topper's talk vidoes on YouTube. Learn about their strategy and book list.Don't ignore NCERTs, especially Class 11th and 12th NCERTs.Make notes of all topics that you cover.Keep referring to syllabus and previous years question papers regularly.For Prelims : Try to develop the art of eliminating options and making intelligent guesses. It would prove very useful.For Mains : try to attempt as much questions as possible and draw relevant diagrams , flow charts wherever necessary. Write in bullet points in GS answers.A balanced preparation, frequent revision and lots of practise , that's the key to succeed in first attempt. Hope it helps.

“FIRST ATTEMPT” This is something which is very difficult but not at all impossible. Actually, there's no use of discussing study techniques or strategy. We are living in 2017, where each and every aspirant is connected with almost every topper/resource/blueprints through Facebook, Twitter, Quora or our favourite @Unacademy, etc. Everything is available on a click. So every aspirant is getting equal access to the resources. So no need to stay in Delhi, Delhi is in your hands. Now what makes a topper….??? Or let's make it simple, what makes candidates to achieve such a rank where they would be eligible for the prestigious All India Services ….??? Following 'philosophies’ are the most common,yet not applied in practice. These will not guarantee you the rank in very first attempt but will surely work for you. AWARENESS  See you cannot fight without knowing your own strengths and weaknesses. It is about YOU. If you don't know what your strengths and weaknesses are, it's waste of time to prepare. Eg: If you're fully aware that you cannot study for long hours, still you are forcing yourself to sustain on table then what is the use…..???? You should be fully aware about yourself before starting the preparation. MOTIVATION Two types, instant and long lasting. I hope you know the difference. So…., Long lasting motivation helps you. You need to endure for approximately 2 years (Even if you go on clearing each stage in first attempt). So do you think instant motivation will work….??? No…. To have a long lasting motivation your WHY must be clear. Why you want to join service….??? Discover the reason first then go ahead with preparation. DEDICATION/CONSISTENCY  Believe me friends. These two things can beat the so called Intelligence many times. Do you think History, Geography, Political Science, Economics, Current affairs and it's analysis require higher IQ….??? It requires dedication/consistency to follow and analyse current affairs. It requires dedication/consistency to revise revise and revise the static part. Above all you need little common sense and a 'genuine interest’ to understand the subject. CONSCIOUS EFFORTS Ph.D is not expected from you in the subjects. You have to study according to syllabus and by referring previous years question papers. Don't be a part of race with your mates, who reads how much or who covers the syllabus fast. Practice writing answers, give some mock tests. Remember this is not a conventional exam which you gave in your school and colleges. Different perspective is needed, One wrong move can take your rank down, and one rank down can throw you away from your dream service. Work hard, BELIEVE in yourself…., you can get through.

One of the most prestigious examination of the world, the civil services stands tall and apart. Before, thinking of clearing it in first attempt, you have to consider the following; Candidates composition:- I would break the composition into percentages so that you may get some clear ideas. Out of total number of candidates appearing:-45% are those who are giving their second attempt.25% are those who are giving their 3rd or 4th attempt.30% are those who will give their first attempt.From above composition, you should keep in mind that all the candidates appearing for this gruelling examination are well groomed and you will have little or no chance of error.Now the question;“What it takes to clear the civil services in first attempt?” Answer is; Dedicated effort:- Since you want to clear the civil services in first attempt, you must try that what you do hits the Bulls eye. Your efforts must be highly concentrated to produce a greater effect. The more the concentrated effort will be, the more will be the chance of success.Minimise your errors:- It happens most of the time that you tend to try different things and do experiments but the fact is it would have the devastating effect. Just stick to the syllabus and go with the flow. This is the thing that will sail you through.Well verse with the facts:- The civil services is not a talent hunt examination which is only for the intelligent. This examination looks for administrators, the one who can withstand the immense pressure thrown at them, the one who can absorb the failure and the one who is mentally robust. With your preparation, you will also have to focus on your personality development.There is no special mantra to clear the examination in the first attempt, just evaluate yourself, develop your confidence and always strive to do the things that seperates you from the rest. You should be able to identify the thin line that seperates the confidence from over-confidence and this identity will sail you through. Originally answered:- How can I crack UPSC in one try? Good luck.

HERE IS A STRATEGY TO HELP YOU PREPARE FLAWLESSLY ALL THE WAY FROM THE BEGINNING SO THAT YOU CAN SECURE YOUR RESULT FOR YOUR DREAM CAREER The students are in the best possible position to prepare for Civil Services examination if they are in their 1st year of graduation. Advantages that a student has being in 1st year of graduation. 1. His/her mind is uncluttered unlike people who have done their graduation and are undergoing some coaching. 2. It’s a fresh canvas on which any picture can be made, anything can be done a clean blackboard on which anything can be written. 3. It is much more easy to mould a student during this period. The flaws in the students can be easily identified and plugged. 4. The students even if they make some initial mistakes can easily get it corrected as they have so much time. 5. It’s easy to shape the personality and do a lot of trial and error to understand oneself. Most of the students actually forget whatever they have learnt during schools after graduation and have to go back to schools and ultimately end up studying at school level only. In any case even students who are doing their coaching, will take take 3 years of time to prepare well and have to go to the basics. This will again compound their difficulty. How to proceed in three years In the three years, during graduation, there are certain things that a candidate has to do. The purpose during the entire three-year period has to build a base which can help the students to better their University examination, form a base on which they can build any type of future. At the same time, they have to be seen by their mentor that they do not develop any attitudinal flaws. Thus they · Must, must and must choose a mentor. · Look for sequencing the topics in such a manner that would minimize efforts in learning a particular topic; content and subject. Phase wise Strategy A phase wise implementation must begin by identifying the problem of the candidates and filling the gaps that have been left in their school education. Phase “1” Foundation Stage. This will will comprise of During this period, the students must train themselves into building social capital, social bonding, reading newspapers, magazines, observe people in editorial and teaching capabilities, etc. and master all school books that they ever studied. All these ingredients are important for the candidates to ease their effort that will be required to gain knowledge in almost every subject a person should know. The essential ingredients have to- · Counsel the parents to bring the best in their child. · Filling the gaps in the education and personality of the candidates. · Improve their language and observation. · Develop in them a balance of perception. · Subject them to Neurolistic-Linguistic Programming (NLP). Thus the most important phase will constitute 1. Complete revision of School books and the practice of their questions and answers. 2. Communication & Body Language Improvement. 3. Language Improvement. 4. Understanding oneself, their parents and teachers. 5. Understanding their surroundings. 6. Learning to make bonds, and social capital. 7. Start Reading Newspapers. 8. Practice basic math and aptitude Phase “2” Knowledge Stage The candidates come to learn the basics of the entire syllabus of UPSC chapterwise. This phase must comprise of Mastery of World Geography, Science and Technology, Geography, Indian and International Economy, International Relations, Indian Polity, Governance, History, Heritage, Culture and SocietyWeekly exchange of news and community education.Learning through various means-Films, Books, Interactions, Parents, Teachers, TV.Basics of Internet and Social Media to utilize online wealth.Background of events and World problems.Socialization studies, principles and applications.Learning to know the means and mechanism of teaching and learning.Continue practicing basic maths and aptitudePhase “3” Interrelationship stage. Having gone through the two stages, all the students will be prepared to take to study certain degree of correlation ship between the topics. Elevate the level by adding extra information and analysis. Develop an analytical ability as well and keep expressing it. Phase “4” After graduation Now you have one year of time to appear for PT. Start organizing yourself, Start moving step by step picking up each topic and completing it, writing at least one answer from the topic, remembering it and revising it thoroughly as you have to appear in that years exam. This should take at least six month from July to December. Phase “5” PT Intensive phase with practice. Having gained enough amount of knowledge, the candidate must take a deep plunge into PT preparation that should comprise of practice and practice and practice and perfecting Newspaper studies. Phase “6” Mains only phase with Intensive writing practice. After PT, go for preparation of Mains and focus has to be on appearing in tests and developing analytical abilities. It has to be Revision, analysis and Tests. This is what should become the norm till the mains Examination.

Hello If you are aiming high then you should prepare yourself for really hard work without any distraction. You should focus only on your aim by sidelining every other things. To clear UPSC in very first attempt you need a proper plan. You have to make plan as per your strength and your weakness. Firstly have a clear idea of the exam pattern and it syllabus, UPSC has a vast syllabus so don't be in a hurry to read everything, understand and follow the syllabus and take your time. Here are few simple thing one should keep in mind while aiming for UPSC exam: You should clear your basics, for that you need to study NCERT books from 6th to 12th standard. Try to clear all your concepts regarding each and every topic. Once you are done with your concepts then go for the reference books or trending books available in market for UPSC topics because they will give present scenario of these topics as UPSC ask for applied knowledge not bookish knowledge. So don't just read try to connect it with present scenario. Make self notes in your own way because these notes gonna help you till the last. As you know you can't read whole book all the time. Join a good coaching for proper guidance and follow their notes. Most important thing for clearing the exam is to practice as much as mock test as you can. It will help you to check your level of preparation and to improve it day by day. Without testing yourself your preparation will go no where.There are several test series available in market. Keep updating your notes.Add all valuable points which you come across while preparing. Don't get distracted by anything, strictly follow your plan everyday. UPSC asks for patience as its a long procedure so be patient and focused. Hope it helps ALL THE BEST

The following are the tips through which you can clear UPSC/IAS Prelims in the first attempt:- 1-Comprehend the UPSC pattern and syllabus:- The questions which are asked in UPSC Prelims are objective type while the descriptive kind of questions is answered in the mains examination. So you don’t have to study in detail for this exam. For proper preparation of the basics, you have to read the NCERT textbooks thoroughly. To get an idea about the format of the questions you can follow the previous year’s question papers. 2-Numerous sources:- There are multiple sources from where you can get the study materials and read online books by well-known scholars, but you have to select the books from where you will study and never get confused by following many books for one single topic. 3-Current Affairs:- Inculcate a habit of reading Hindu, times of India, Indian Express or any other magazine which you prefer for reading for current affairs. You can even browse online through the websites of these newspapers on the trending topics in different sectors such as science and technology, socio and economic and national and international issues. 4-Strategic planning & defined goals:- This point might be a bit confusing with this is the most critical point which is the backbone for clearing prelims in your first attempt. Before you start your preparation you have to plan your timetable appropriately for daily, weekly and monthly basis. Also, plan how many hours you will study daily. With planning, it is also vital that you set goals which you have to scrutinize whether they are accomplished in the stipulated duration of time or not. Through proper planning and set goals you will cover your entire syllabus in time. 5-Revision:- The prelims syllabus is very vast, and revision is significant for every topic and subject. It is a very crucial work to revise the entire syllabus before the examination from those fat books. Revision can be best done through the notes; self-made notes are best for revising just before your exam. 6-Practice test series:- It is vital to practice the aptitude tests which cover the logical reasoning, comprehension, mental ability, etc. Practicing these tests will help you a lot in clearing the prelims paper in your first attempt.

If you have an ambition to be an IAS you have to go through CSE( Civil Services Exam) conducted annually by UPSC. This is one of the toughest exam in the whole world. Now (MY OPINION) it hardly matters how much you study, What matters is What you study and how much you grasped from that(WHATS YOUR OUTPUT - That matters). And the First thing i believe before starting preparation (FOR ANY EXAM) we must be familiar with the exam pattern (So first thing surf net and grasp all about CSE exam pattern) Now coming back to preparation strategy : Start with S.ST.(Comprising Geography, History, Economics, Polity) OLD NCERT (From 6th to 12th).Read newspaper (THE HINDU Preferred ) daily and jot down the important news lines( i.e - National and International Issues, Sports and Economic updates, Government policies, and Awards)For Essay - Read editorials daily from newspaper because most of the times essay come upon current events. So newspaper will be of great help.General Studies : BOOKSFacts of Indian Culture (New Edition by Spectrum)India after Independence - Bipan ChandraIndia After Gandhi - Ramchandra GuhaIndia's Struggle for Independence - Bipan ChandraGeography of India – Majid Husain .Indian Polity - M. LaxmikantIndian economy - Ramesh SinghEthics, Integrity and aptitude - lexicon publicationsSOME ONLINE STUDY SITES :Home Ministry WebsiteMoEF WebsiteMinistry of S & T WebsiteGk TodayA few things that can be followed to this Voyage are : MIND SET - Before beginning with preparation it’s very essential part of the journey that one has to make his/her mind set. Mind set for the questions which will arise many times - Why I am preparing ? What will I achieve from this ? Is it really my Aim or I am just forced to do ? Am I am that strong to face the defeat or I am too strong enough to beat the defeat ?- Make you goal. Don't aim for success if you want it; just do what you love and believe in, and it will come naturally. UNDERSTAND THE SYLLABUS - UPSC is a lengthy process. Begin it with understanding it. 1st step should be download the syllabus from Internet. If possible have it’s hard copy and paste it near your study table or any place where you can read it twice a day. This will help you understand and will remind you that - UPSC isn’t about everything under the sun. Moreover you will be familiar with what to do and what to follow.-“If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles  STRATEGY OR THE WEAPON : To begin this journey it’s very important to follow good strategy. Here, Instead of copying the toppers way of preparation follow yourself, ask yourself a question - to find out the best. You know yourself better than anyone else. Have a clear mind, Instead of working hourly divide your work to be done daily regardless of time. Once in a week take out a day to revise the material you have done in rest 6 days.SUCCESS MANTRA :Believing in yourselfCultivating a success mindsetOvercoming procrastinationHard workNot making excusesPerseveranceHAVE A ROLE MODEL - There should be a person whose footsteps you can follow. The one by whose achievements you are really inspired, the one who can be the source of motivation when you feel low.- A role model is a mentor - someone you see on a daily basis, and you learn from them. AVOID DISTRACTIONS - There will be time when you will be having choice to mug up books or instead share a plate of Cheppankizhangu Chops or some meal with your friend at another’s party or perhaps weeding. But remember these are just distractions. You have a aim which is more valuable then leaving a few ceremonial occasions. The best way is to cut off from the social life for just a few months and stay focused.- A leader is best when people barely know he exists, when his work is done, his aim fulfilled, they will say: we did it ourselves.

I don’t know whether I am the right person to answer this question or not . It is difficult to predict whether you will be able to clear this exam in the first attempt or even the last attempt. UPSC CSE is an exam of colossal magnitude and a “logistical challenge” in itself. Moreover UPSC is not called “Unpredictable Service Commission” in the aspirant community for absolutely no reason. Even if you prepare very well and do everything right (which is mathematically very improbable if not impossible), a lot of things can go wrong in this exam at any of the levels. The biggest problem with this exam is that even if you fail at the last stage and by say even 1 mark, you don’t get any consolation prize as in you have to start from the scratch again and it might happen that you may fail to clear prelims itself in this year even though might have gotten selected in the previous year (as it happened to a friend of mine who got IRTS last year and couldn’t even clear prelims this year). it is very important to know what not to read even more than what to read. Moreover people think that if someone cleared in the first attempt, everyone can. It may or may not happen. Because someone who clears in first attempt, may have been preparing for a long time before writing the exam e.g. Tina Dabi who had been preparing since 2011, or they must have been very well read even before writing the exam e.g. Prakash Rajpurohit or they might have been simply gifted e.g. Shah Faisal. And this might not be the case with every other aspirant. That is not to imply that this exam can not be prepared and cleared in the first attempt. It can certainly be done. I am below giving in brief the mistakes I committed and how to avoid them so as to better your chances to clear this exam in first attempt. If you want to know in detail you can read my answer I have mentioned above. Here’s some of the mistakes one should avoid ( taken from my answer): Wishfully thinking and daydreaming that one would clear this exam. Most of the time one keeps on planning on what and how to read;thinking about what one would do after clearing the exam and what not, and not actually reading. This is detrimental.Not taking a holistic perspective of this exam. Taking all the different stages as disparate entities whereas this exam is an integrated exam.Being overconfident about one’s abilities. Even if you are/have been a topper throughout your academic or career, you still have to cover a mammoth syllabus which will take time and hard work. And in my opinion intelligence is hyped concept. So many Doctors, IITians & IIM grads fail to clear this exam every year despite putting in efforts. What is required is a very well planned strategy and a lot of hard work and belief in one’e abilities and not overconfidence.Mixing personal with professional. We all go through tough phases in life. But if you let it affect your preparation you are doomed. So one needs to be able to separate personal from professional.Choosing popular optionals. I took Geo and Pub Ad. Got butchered in 2012. Whereas a friend of mine took Physics and Maithili and became an IAS in 2012 (I had more marks than him in Interview and Essay and similar marks in GS). I am not saying that one should not take these optionals, but be ready for getting lower average marks than other not so popular optionals say Economics.Not making notes. Notes are absolutely necessary for revision and retaining information. So unless you have eidetic memory like Sherlock you’d be better off making notes.Only reading and not revising. Biggest mistake one can make. Because after a certain time information evaporates from the mind unless you revise it. So always revise at regular intervals.Unbalanced preparation. Focusing on one area at the cost of others. Cost me my 2015 attempt as I didn’t focus on CA properly.There can be many other aspects that may bring you down. All you need to do is to be dedicated, hard working and have a well planned strategy for preparation. And avoid the mistakes others have made and you should be able to clear this exam in the very first attempt. Note: I will update this answer if I come up with new ideas. Stay tuned. Clearing this exam in the very first attempt depends on a lot of other factors many of which are not in control of an average aspirant. For example the biggest reason why people from ivy league colleges like IITs, IIMs etc clear this exam in disproportionate numbers is the exposure they get in their colleges. They have world class faculty, better study environments, and most importantly a vibrant and top notch peer group. So they generally don’t make the same mistakes the average aspirants make. I will give you an example. In my first attempt since I didn't have any idea of what to read, I used to read “ChronicKill” (Chronicle) magazine which was tremendous waste of time and energy. But at the same time I had a co aspirant from IIT Delhi (who eventually cleared in his first attempt) and he laughed at us for reading that magazine and never read it. He read basic books and NCERTs and cleared. Since there is so much study material available and so many different strategies floating around it becomes very difficult to know what to read and what not to. And in this exam If you wish, you can also follow me and read my articles on gradeup!

Tips for cracking Civil Service Exam on the first attempt ? Every student having so many doubts about this examination. Their first doubt was whether they have to join in any coaching center or is it good to go for self learning i.e. through online YouTube videos or going through other available websites which provide civil service examination related stuff. Ideas to be kept in mind during Preparation : Many students felt that cracking IAS Exam in first attempt was difficult, but this exam can be easily cracked in first attempt with proper strategical planning and implementation. Mock Tests plays a crucial role, so please consider them seriouslyDon't get confuse for choosing different sources for a single topic / subject, pick one source for one topic and stick to itBefore starting the preparation be well-prepared with your plan and implementationCheck your skills by daily attempting mock tests so that you will be assess your performanceLet's have a look at YouTube videos too which provide a neat and fair explanation related to each and every topicPrelims Preparation : Provide a dedicated time i.e at least 8-9 hours for 3 monthsIt's important that not only going through standard books underline the important topicsMake habit of reading newspaper and tried to attempt maximum questionsAfter completion of mock test assess yourself and prepare a document in which topic your are showingpoor performance and concentrate on that particular criteriaGo through the mock tests provided by different institutes before the last week of examinationTry to attempt previous question papers tooMains : After completion of prelims exam you will be knowing that how to plan for mains as you already made a strategical plan in preparing for prelims Divide Your day in 3 parts : Newspaper Reading and Writing practice : Speedy writing and fast thinking is the main criteria for this examinationOptional Subject : provide at least 4-5 hours timeGS Subjects : spend 6 -7 hoursTh important thing you should not forgot was to go through the mock test and previous question papers which helps you in assessing you performance Answer Writing Tips : Introduction : 30 - 40 words which explain the essence of questions askedMain Body : 130 -150 words - write in bullet pointsExamples : Include Examples through providing diagrams. maps etc.Conclusion : 20 -30 words, should be positive and involve some innovative suggestion#crackiasinfirstattempt #targetias

Always remain focused on your main goal, do not divert yourself. Always keep reminding yourself that you have to clear your exam in the first attempt. Most of the Candidates have the habit of preparing for different competitive exams simultaneously to play safe. In such case, your minds get diverted. You must realize that properly preparing for the civil services exam is not a part-time job. It is a fact that if you are fully devoted to preparing for the civil services exam without pursuing any other studies, competitive exams or job. Your concentration level will be at its peak, and this would give you the best results. The desire to grab one job or the other and playing it safe leads to failure on all fronts. As the famous saying goes, ‘ a man sailing on two different boats at the same time reaches nowhere.’

First all be cent percent convinced about choosing IAS as a career option. Write down honest reasons of why u want to join bureaucracy. It's necessary to keep ur spirit high during the course of preparation. Now coming to ur query, you can start with- 1. Reading one english daily like -The hindu , livement, Indian express etc . Avoid picking up Times of India,else u might get lost into arresting pics and useless stuff :) 2. Initially u might not understand more than 70-80% of issues in newspapers. But dnt panic. A solution to this is reading only editorial and cover page for initial one month. Be ready with ur laptop or tablet to google all u can . Initially for 10-20 days, read only 1 article of editorial and make jottings on the given issue as and when u browse through net. 3. Pick up Ncerts (CBSE) of any one subject out of - Economics, History, Geography, Environment, Polity etc. Read all ncerts of a subject (6th -10th class) at a stretch before moving to other subject. 11th and 12th class ncerts of respective subjects should be done in second round of reading, after u r done with 6-10 class ncerts of all above mentioned subjects. 4. U can  parallelly check out sites like: UNACADEMY, INSIGHTS ON INDIA, MRUNAL, FORUMIAS, IASBABA and so on. They are a good source to learn concepts you find difficult to understand. But dnt spend too much time online.  5.. One imp aspect is to keep looking to syllabus and past year prelims papers as u proceed with ur preparation. It will orient ur preparation as per demands of Upsc. Do this first for 3months,it will give u a headstart. And u can further build upon it easily. Good luck!!

Follow the SMS Approach. S: Study Material M: Mocks S: Strategy Study Material to clear the exam If one thinks that he/she needs to read HUNDREDS of books, browse TENS of websites and prepare notes from FIVE newspapers and TEN magazines each day to clear IAS, THIS IS WRONG. The exaggerated actions are neither practical nor necessary to clear CSE. Even if an imaginary person does all what is stated above, there is still chance that he/she not clear Prelims/Mains. So what matters is not the quantity of materials one had gone through, but the quality of learning and revision done. Importance of Mocks to clear the exam Mocks are nothing but practice/trials that one takes before the final battle. Indian Cricket Team was criticized for not taking practice matches in their tour of South Africa in 2019. What is more shocking is that they repeated the same mistake in the tour of England. And the final result in both the cases is known to all…There are a lot of benefits of taking mocks… They help in overcoming the fear psychosis and enable one not to panic in the exam hall. They help in understanding the nuances of the exam.Many aspirants do not have the practice for sitting for 3 hours at a stretch and that too for two times a day and for 5 days in a week.They help in making management strategy for the real exam eg: how much time to be devoted for each question.They help in knowing ones’ strengths and weaknesses, doing self-analytics.Mocks help in preparing topics which have not been covered. They provide extra vital information.They help in developing speed, refining the thought process. THEY HELP IN HONING ONE’S ATTITUDE AND THINKING PROCESS.Mocks help one to face the tremendous competition by honing their skills to achieve considerably high and safe score of atleast 120+.They help one to tackle uncertainties, boost exam preparedness and improve ones’ score and rank.Mocks help one to gain a real time experience of facing esteemed panel of experts and learn the art to excel under critical analysis and review of the experts.Smart Study to clear the exam:Few easy-to-implement tips to study smart for UPSC Exam Learn in multiple waysRead multiple subjects in one dayAvoid multitaskingTake handwritten notesLearn by associationRevise periodicallySimplify the informationPractice testsKnow what to filterRead textbooks effectivelyDon’t cram, understandRead important information out loudReward yourselfTake a break and make those breaks happening but in a way that one gets back to preparation with double the zeal and enthusiasm.

“Unbreakable will power is the ultimate key to accomplish any goal that you set in your life”  UPSC is generally taken as a very hard nut to crack. People go on preparing and appearing for it years and years but still don’ t get succesful. On the other side of the story, there are people who have prepared just for 9–10 months with all their heart and soul and have cleared it in their first attempts. Its not about what people say, its about why have you chosen to appear in this examination that will drive you towards achieving this or any goal of yours. Keeping in mind clearing the UPSC in first attempt, the following tips may be beneficial: “Keep your goal in front of your eyes”. You need to remember it the whole time what are you preparing for.“By heart the syllabus”. Learn the syllabus in the best possible way. You don’t need to study anything out of the syllabus.“Keep your sources precise”. Read very less but read it thoroughly.“Revise more”. Read less and revise more should be the ultimate mantra.“Analyse the question papers of the previous years.” Understand the pattern of questions that are asked in the exam.“Attempt test series from the very first day of your preparation”. Don’t wait for your syllabus to complete for appearing in test.“ Make a proper strategy” according to you and follow it religiously.“ Keep your circle very small”. No need of any toxicity around you.“Stay in touch with positive people” who encourage you to get your goal.In the free time, “engage yourself in motivating activities”. This will help you keep up the pace of preparation.With strong self believe, you can move mountains, this is just an exam. Hope it helps you all! Regards, Kriti

Preparing for India’s most prestigious exam in an arduous task and clearing it in the first attempt is rather more challenging. It requires systematic and smart preparation techniques to be followed. Neostencil brings you some of the finest tips from experienced professionals and successful IAS aspirants which will help you to crack the UPSC exam in the first attempt. Don’t underestimate yourself Have faith and dedicated belief in yourself that you can hit the EXAM. If you think you are a faint hearted person and cannot prepare for UPSC, then you are wrong. Rather IAS preparation makes you stone hearted. Secondly, don’t compare yourself with anyone. Every individual has its own strengths and weaknesses. Work upon them and you will perfectly sail in the ocean of UPSC. Go for the most recommended books The first step towards your dream is, having all the study material readily available. The most recommended books for UPSC preparation are the NCERT books. Once you have finished them (preferable by the end of third month of your preparation period), it’s time to move on to some standard books. Prioritize your time Instead of hardwork, you should go for SMART work. A perfect blend of both will fetch you high ranks in the result list. In the initial period of your preparation, work on your weaker areas or the areas you feel requires more of concept clearing. If you are preparing on your own, then online video tutorials are best options for clearing the concepts. Prepare a perfect time table and follow it strictly. Read Newspaper everyday Make a habit of reading the newspaper daily. It not only will make you aware of the happenings around the world but will also help you in your preparation for current affairs. While going through the newspaper you must pay extra attention on the events, names and places. Give a little extra time on editorial section of the newspaper as it will help you in your essay writing preparation. Work on your speed and accuracy Continue reading: http://thinkpedia.in/how-to-crack-upsc-in-first-attempt.php

IT IS A GAME OF TEMPERAMENT AND YOUR GRIT Your discipline, perseverance, and consistency can help you become an IAS officer, in the first attempt itself. It is a game of perseverance, grit, and hard work rather than intelligence. Preparation requires 12–13 months of time, provided you study 5–6 hours per day on an average. (Whatever circumstances you may be in if you can devote this much time to it, it is 100% achievable) Begin by going through the syllabus of UPSC, know about the pattern of the examination, and then start with your preparation. Indian Polity, Indian History, Indian Geography, and Indian Economy are the pillars od UPSC IAS Preparation. Start with Laxmikant for Indian polity, with persistent hard work, this book can be completed in 30–45 days. The focus should be on understanding rather than on rote learning. For Indian History, read NCERT Modern INDIA and NCERT Ancient India by RS Sharma. Make notes out of it. This can be done in 2 months time. For Indian Geography refer NCERTs of Class 11 and 12. For Physical geography, GC Leong is also good. Again it can be completed in 30 days. For the Indian Economy, read NCERT for classes 11 and 12. Use the internet and Ramesh Singh for reference (not to be read cover to cover). Read the newspaper regularly, once you are done with your foundation subjects, you will make more sense out of it. All through your preparation, keep going through the syllabus regularly so that it gets engraved in your mind. It will be your constant guide in your preparation. And, never hesitate to reach out to your teachers or those students who have gone through the process, make sure to learn from their experience as well. Good Luck. Raja Rajyavardhan GS Faculty at, Plutus IAS

Assuming that you are a beginner Step 1: Please do start reading newspaper(Hindu or Indian Express) and get accustomed with the things happening in our country Step 2: Check websites like Insights or Iasbaba( Both have Great Quality)- especially daily current events ( just after accustomed with Step 1) because it helps you to unlearn the irrelevant part from newspaper Step 3: Check the syllabus and study only the relevant portions or do plan roughly what to read and when to read Step 4: Take some Ncert books or else do follow Online classes of Unacademy, as these days those people are active and providing many classes for free, definitely it will help you to understand the basics even if you miss Ncert, but if you read by yourself, some doubts may be demolished by checking those videos Step 5: By following all the steps stated above without skipping them, will make you to know what to read and what not to, and the further steps can be known to you by this time. All the best and hope it helps you a little.

Cracking CSE in first attempt is dream of all but achieved by few. Still one can try following: Start preparation 1 year before the targeted prelims.Select optional carefully.Prepare optional along with notes in first few months of preparation.Know what exactly to read for prelims and start with it.Make notes for prelims.Regular tests and revision of tests.Newspaper reading for prelims and then mains.Answer writing practice for mains along with prelims.Mains test series after prelims.Concise notes and revision for mains.Interview preparation post mains invloving discussions.It is too broad question. Answering it is tough. Doing it is tougher. But not impossible. Key is to start well. ATB!

It depends on Guidance - topper, senior, brother, websites etc.How motivated you areHow focused you can be and how well you can handle mood swingsHow mature you are (how quickly you learn from your mistakes; how well you plan and execute)Study resources - websites, books etc.Luck, writing skills, attitude (easy going or nervous) etc.Time factor - preparation with job or full time preparationStudy environment - home, hostel etc.How well you understand the scheme of the examination - syllabus, question papers, trend etc.Background (rural, urban, regional language or English medium)Support from parents and financial support.Friend circle and relatives - supportive or time wastingThere is no fixed metric to tell about the time required to clear UPSC CSE. It depends on many factors including luck. There are people that cleared the exam in their 1st attempt with 1–1.5 years of preparation while many others took 2,3,4,5 or more years. Analyse the above factors and decide to yourself the time that you need to clear the exam. Here I tried to guess based on the most determining aspects Guidance: Good Guidance = you can clear the exam in 1.5 years.No guidance = you make struggle in 1–2 attempts. 3 yearsMotivation: High levels of motivation + good guidance = 1–1.5 yearsLow levels of motivation = It depends on after how many failure you changeJob: With job + well motivated = 2 years, 1–2 attemptsWithout job + well motivated = 1–1.5 years, 1 attemptMedium Regional language = depends on the person. Usually it takes some time. But there are people who have cleared it in first attempt (Good guidance + motivation).Background Rural + Home staying take more time because of various reasons like not so ambient study environment, lack of internet and other facilities.

Howdy aspirants!! Determined Approach - From beginning decides it's going to be your final & last attempt. Set your mind that you are going to crack UPSC CSE in a first go! Never think of other attempts and built your mindset to crack the UPSC CSE in your first go. Day and day out tell yourself to do it in the first attempt and put the requisite work in the place. Here your proficiency is directly inverse to your number of attempts Keep optimistic and don't let anyone run into your task of cracking such exam and telling you it will need more than 1 attempt: Do not get into other people thoughts keep your focus and mind on the first go!! Guidance is the way for this exam. Having a mentor that can guide you in the right direction is of pivotal importance. UPSC coaching institute or Self-preparation: Admission into an eminent UPSC coaching institute gives you the mentorship and educational tools required for such exam clearance and it gives you manifold boost to your UPSC aspirations. Just don’t follow into selfish marketing swindles or any cheap UPSC coaching institutes. Before joining get into a detailed query of the UPSC coaching institute, asked friends, or students, or search the internet. Just be smart & different as thousands of students go for UPSC preparation, getting the same thing and the only difference is your attitude. Or, go for Self-preparation: Going for self-study has only one downfall i.e. guidance or mentorship. Self-preparation is by far the best method preparing for any exam only if you have the right direction in the form of whether it’s a teacher, ex-UPSC family member, friends, peers or toppers or online guidance from an expert. UPSC exam needs perseverance & consistency coupled with smart work & mentorship. Mistake and Repeat: Cracking UPSC in a first attempt going to be you doing plenty of mistakes and that’s good. Nothing ever comes from sitting idle or doing nothing. Try different things, do mistakes, repeat it again and most important learn it from the mistakes & successfully implement them. Watch the pattern of all different year UPSC exam, behaviour of students wasting years or months cracking this exam. Learned from it, their old & new habits and be optimistic. Negativity doesn’t do anything good to you. Keep dreaming & believing in your dreams & yourself Be Motivated Never give up Dreams!!

This question was originally answered by someone else. This post is generally applicable to any serious candidate, for any examination, etc I appreciate your vibe for a sharp target. There are just a few suggestions that you can utilize for sharpening your daily work habits and move closer towards your target. Before anything, shut your ears while receiving any negative vibe conversation from relatives, peer groups or any person. Give a sweet smile on their face and do what you need to do for yourself.Always have the habit of talking to your exam-related seniors. They may give a useful strategy and shortcuts. At the same time learn from their mistakes. In the end, you want what you want, a craving attitude to pass any competitive examination.Take time to analyse yourself. Experiment with yourself, like, see at what time you can wake up in your normal biological clock without alarms, see which kind of pen gives you a fast and smooth handwriting, how long you engage in physical activities, social life, whether you take a nap after a meal, whether you are good at newspapers, etc. All these add up to how you understand yourself.After a thorough self-understanding make possible positive changes gradually, not suddenly.Start with your Hindu Newspaper, PIB, etc OR get the current affairs monthly compilation of a recommended institute and read at least 20–30 pages daily. Make notes.Plan your schedule and stick to it religiously. Plan the schedule for ‘basic concepts’ and ‘building concepts’ separately.Gather materials for your basic concepts and kick start your fundamental preparations. Get your fundamentals strong and holding. Refer to Google, NCERTs or any material that suits you.Always follow Revise-Repeat-Revise-Repeat strategy… Keep a weekly target (highly recommended), fortnight target (if you need) and a monthly target (highly recommended). Make appropriate notes. They come handy during revision.Choose the right books for building your concepts. The market is generally pumped with a lot of good materials. Initially, you may find difficulty in choosing a book for a subject. Do take the advice of seniors and surf the internet for its comments and reviews before choosing the material. If possible, some books offer a sample PDF format. Take your time and read a couple of chapters. If you are okay with it, start your run according to the schedule. Many of my friends after reaching half a book get tired with it and get thought-saturated, i.e., they find it difficult to understand the subject further. Later they regret. So choose wisely. Even if you are in any similar condition don’t regret because you have to regret. Rather change to a simpler book or Google only the part that you didn’t understand. In the end, nobody in exam gonna asks you from which book you studied this and that. All you need is information converted to knowledge and knowledge converted to wisdom. That wisdom will work in the exam, irrespective of what material you saw, heard or experienced.Again follow Revise-Repeat-Revise-Repeat strategy… Keep a weekly target (highly recommended), fortnight target (if you need) and a monthly target (highly recommended). Make appropriate notes. They come handy during revision.Testing is the most important aspect of any examination. You should know how much you absorbed from how much you grabbed from how much you had. The market is generally flooded with a lot of good test series. Find the appropriate one after consulting your exam related seniors. Give each test in an exam simulated environment. Get it corrected and revise the whole test again. Attach test revision schedule to your normal revision schedule and brush it out left right and centre.Answer writing practice. Meanwhile, if your exam consists of writing answers, practice answer writing once a week, get it corrected from a couple of seniors who have a good hold in their answers. Take the suggestions and implement them effectively.Just before 90–100 days of your preliminary examination, start revising your revision notes and take enough tests to boost your confidence levels.Before a day of your exam relax and talk to yourself (you’ll eventually know what you should talk to yourself ;)Take time to sharpen yourself. P.S. Join a coaching institute ONLY IF YOU NEED. Keep your vibe young and burning. All the best :)

Some general Informations about this exam:- UPSC conducts this exam every year. It is conducted in three phases namely prelims ,mains and interview.Prelims consists of 2 papers . Paper 1 and paper 2. All are multiple choice types.Paper 1 is based on general studies (humanities subjects like history, geography,economy,polity and general science as well as current affairs ).While paper 2 is based on quantitative aptitude,english etc. This paper is qualifying in nature whose qualifying mark is fixed at 33%.After qualifying prelims comes mains exam. It has 4 gs papers,one optional consisting 2 papers and 1 essay paper. There are also one english and one religional language papers which are again qualifying papers and marks of these papers are not taken into account for deciding the merit list.After qualifying in mains exam comes the interview.Both interview marks and marks in 7 papers of mains are added up to make the final merit list.Each paper of mains is descriptive and carries 250 marks and interview itself carries 275 marks . So total mark is 2025.You can get more details from UPSC CSE notification and syllabus. Now come to your question. After deciding to give the exam don't look back. Give 6–7hrs of dedicated study per day without any distractions. Give 2–3hrs at max for newspaper reading. Read The Hindu or The Indian Express. Read standard ncert books at the primary stage for the rest 3–4 hrs,revise them once then go to other books. I am reproducing the book list from one of my previous answers below:- Ncert books of 11th & 12th for geography.Ancient history by RS Sharma, Medieval History by Satish Chandra and modern history ncert book by Bipin ChandraIndian Polity by m. Laxmikanth (you may additionally read 11th ncert book on Indian constitution at work)12th Ncert book on Introductry Macroeconomics.6th-10th science ncery and last four chapters of 12th biology ncert on ecology.**If you can't understand any concept then refer to 6th-10th of respective subject or just google it or watch some videos on youtube from mrunal or unacademy etc. After completing this stage your syllabusplays the crucial role. If you want something to mug up in this process then consider your syllabus first.Read it as many times as you can and remember every topics ,subtopics and key words of it. Prelims syllabus is not datailed so for this you have already read basic books and current affairs from newspaper. But mains Syllabus is more detailed and you can see it's importance after watching previous year's papers. Be selective and use syllabus as a map to reach the destination. In the next stage read the following books….. India's struggle for independence by Bipin Chandra or Spectrum’s brief history of modern India.India since independence,only selective chapters.Arts and culture by Nitin Singhania or facets of Indian culture of spectrum’s.Certificate physical and human geography by GC Leong.Environment book of Shankar IAS .Eeconomy selected chapters of Ramesh Singh or Sanjeeb Verma.Sociology 11th ,12th ncert book.Ethics book of lexicon.After all these you have to cover other portions like IR,disaster management etc of your gs syllabus and optional. Govt. websites like PIB, IDSA and Yojana Magazine are to be referred. Vision ias monthly CA is very important. Economic survey is very important for all three stages of the exam. ARC report is also of very much importance. If you are doing self study then follow insights on India and use all it's initiatives. Practice test series as much you can. For paper 2 of prelims which is qualifying give less time but practice previous year papers and take some test series. For mains , Answer writting is the key . After a successful journey till the mains take some mock interviews and give your best before the board and be ready to see your name in the pdf of final list. Try your best, give your best cause you have nothing to do with the rest……………That's all I had to say.

Reduce your social media interaction to nil. And cut down on your social interactions like attending weddings and birthdays and parties. They can come later on . Make sure you stay healthy and hydrated af all times. Keep a cheerful countenance and stay friendly at home. Don't do joint studies and no overnighters. Best wishes

Once I was also struggling to find the answer to these questions, there is a blog which provided me with the best answer to it. Numerous candidates appear for UPSC/IAS /Civil Services exams to wants become an IAS officer in future. To become an IAS officer, you have to clear all the three examination- Prelims, Mains and Interview which is also called the personality test. Undoubtedly you have to prepare rigorously and with utmost dedication, if you want to clear every examination in your first attempt. The following are the tips through which you can clear UPSC/IAS Prelims in the first attempt:- 1-Comprehend the UPSC pattern and syllabus:- The questions which are asked in UPSC Prelims are objective type while the descriptive kind of questions is answered in the mains examination. So you don’t have to study in detail for this exam. For proper preparation of the basics, you have to read the NCERT textbooks thoroughly. To get an idea about the format of the questions you can follow the previous year’s question papers. 2-Numerous sources:- There are multiple sources from where you can get the study materials and read online books by well-known scholars, but you have to select the books from where you will study and never get confused by following many books for one single topic. 3-Current Affairs:- Inculcate a habit of reading Hindu, times of India, Indian Express or any other magazine which you prefer for reading for current affairs. You can even browse online through the websites of these newspapers on the trending topics in different sectors such as science and technology, socio and economic and national and international issues. to read more points kindly click on the link- http://bestiascoachinginindia.com/2018/04/22/post-3/

I will divide the strategy into three parts :- Static Portion - It can be covered with the combination of NCERT and basic books on each topic. For Ex. Lakshmikant for Polity, Spectrum for History etc. Also do study maps properly. Current Affairs - Read one or two newspaper and make notes out of it. I used to read only Indian Express till prelims but now I also read The Hindu . You can supplement your notes with monthly current affairs of any coaching institute (I used VisionIAS) Two months before Prelims - This time will be exclusively used for targeting prelims :- Solve a large number of mock test (I solved around 60 mock test of VisionIAS, Insights) - UPSC prelims question paper will be different but this will help you in getting questions related to govt. schemes or current affairs correct. Also try to do a little research on the questions asked in mocks. DO yearly compilation of current affairs of any coaching Institute( I used Vision Pt365). Do not leave any stone unturned. UPSC will play with question papers every year but 60–70 questions can be solved easily with this strategy as UPSC only plays with 25–30 questions, rest are always on the same line. All d Best for Prelims 2018.

If you are preparing for IAS exam and have a very common question in your mind that whether one-year preparation is sufficient for clearing IAS exam or not, you are at the right place. This article will help you to break all your doubts regarding your IAS exam preparation. Your success in IAS depends as much on your preparation as on your luck. That is why I would recommend writing as many attempts as possible because if you toss the dice several times, you have much better chances of getting a six. While the paper of IAS prelims is objective and you need to have precise knowledge of the subject, the IAS Mains is subjective and there is ample room for imagination and creative writing. If you are aware of the topic even remotely, you can write a beautiful answer and if your examiner like that answer, you can also get excellent marks. In my view, one year is good enough for preparing for IAS. It means that if you wish to write CSE next year, you must start preparing by June. Here the presumption is that you will complete your NCERTs, 5-6 most recommended standard books, optional subject, ethics and essay till December. If you can give one year of time for CSE and if you follow this timeline, you have a fairly good chance of cracking CSE. In subsequent years, you can devote much lesser time for preparation, in case you don’t get through the CSE or did not get the service of your choice. All the best.

First of all it is very very tough to clear the UPSC in first attempt. Let us be realistic about our goals and try not to do things which are impossible and end up getting frustrated. An aspirant needs one solid year of preparation under good guidance and One solid year of writing practice before u crack the examination. (Writing practice can be done in the second year, attempting the UPSC exam in parallel if u r talented enough). Please do not fall for any shortcut preparation techniques, as these things are nothing but bullshit. It is only Smartwork that will save you. Pushing yourself too much with “artificial motivations “ will suck up the energy that u have. So a natural growth which is evolutionary in character is always advisable. Sit back, relax, think and move ahead with your preparation. Once you are done with one year of all possible groundwork, go ahead, launch yourself. One attempt is more than enough to crack the exam. If by chance u miss it, try ur luck the second time. I wish u all the best..

There are only two ways to success Make mistakes and learn from them… improve upon them to get best out of you.Learn from other’s mistakes and get the best out of you+circumstances in the first attempt itself.I believe you are talking about the second path. When you have a mentor/elder, who has cleared this exam earlier, s/he lets you know the mistakes and experiences better. Second path is easy in that case. But, what to do if you do not have any mentor? I would suggest a combination of both the above ways. You learn from your mistakes but not on annual basis. Learn from them on daily basis. Improve everyday upon yourself. Every morning should see a better improved version of you. Usual mistake, which makes us take longer time, we learn from mistakes only after UPSC pdf tells us and it takes years. Daily improvements will help you clearing in first attempt itself.Take benefit of online resources/strategies by toppers to compensate the gap for mentor. While, there are several methods suggested by toppers and sometimes it becomes confusing which one will suit you. Customize their plan as per your strength and weakness.Read less, revise more and apply even more. Learn to apply things, be it objective paper, answer writing or interview delivery skills. Hardwork and smartwork should go in parallel.All the best!!

Here are a few pointers: First be thorough with the syllabus of CSE. Start with NCERTs. Move on to supplementary books. Each day keep time for Current affairs and make notes from the newspapers. Micro and macro manage your time. Always set achievable targets and work towards achieving them. Here's my booklist: Geography NCERT 6–12th GC Leong Atlas History Spectrum Bipin Chandra Old NCERTs Economics Sanjeev Verma 11th NCERT and micro economics parts of 12th NCERT Selective Ramesh Singh Economic survey Society 12th sociology NCERT Polity making of constitution NCERT Laxmikant Selective DD Basu Ethics Lexicon Environment Shankar IAS Vision PT365 of the year for environment Newspapers and magazines The Hindu Indian Express for opinion page Yojana Rest for governance, IR, internal security, science and tech and defence, no special book is there in my booklist. I cover all with the help of the newspaper.

Clearing UPSC require less and Limited assistance from outside and more efforts and consistency from yourself. First of All you should be ready to put in all the hardship require. After it All that you need from outside are List of books and guidance on what all topics are required to be read and in how much detail.What approach to be followed while studyingDoubt clearing sessionsinstructions on how to make notes (it varries person to person and totally based on person's natural way of learning)Maintainance of Motivation level. etc.After these things it hardly matters wheather you take coaching, live in Delhi or in your native place, and other things. The above mentioned points can be summed as Mentorship. It is very important to find a good mentor in UPSC preparation, who know you as an individual, knows your potential, your strenght and weaknesses and guide you accordingly. I have attended many coachings in my UPSC journey and went through many coachings, But none have I found as good as Jigyasa IAS in this regard. They provide very good mentorship, they check my daily progress, give me personal advices, help me in all topics. The personal touch in mentorship they provide is not available anywhere. As a Student of the academy I will strongly recommend it to everyone.

First Prepare yourself Before starting your preparation, prepare mentally and physically for examination. Set the goals and devote time effectively.
